V1bK3FzS-W8Ut0s6XRaQyw.text: I heard so much about this place and understand it takes forever to get a reservation. I've been to many steakhouses and I have to say I wasn't overly impressed.  My steak was good, the sides were mediocre (we had the mushrooms and the macaroni and cheese). The most annoying thing was that at around 10 they claimed to "really need our table" whilst there were quite a few open ones around us. We were still ordering drinks- expensive champagne - and there was clearly no need for our table.  I wouldn't go back...

WPLw0sFqvH0hyFkOoRKo2g.text: This is now my favourite steak place in London and in my top ten for all of London. Everything I ate here is excellent. From the steak, burgers, salads, mac and cheese, bread, etc. Great, fresh ingredients, simply done, good portions. Not cheap but totally worth it.

KZx4q6Z-hi75kKhTTieAFw.text: This is the best steak place I've tried in London. Service was amazing and the steaks are insanely good. Chips are also best I've had in London. They're also on twitter which is great for feedback @HawksmoorLondon. I advise to book mind.

k0AbAJpXUd7Hb-_Atr1UNQ.text: "Hawksmoor? I've been wanting to go there for ages!" seems to be a common refrain amongst those as yet uninitiated in the ways of this none-too-minor celebrity venue on the London carnivores' circuit. Two of the most oft-cited reasons are the cocktails and the generously-proportioned, exquisitely-prepared, Ginger Pig-sourced steaks - both of which I've now sampled. I went along with a gang of 10 to an evening organised 'specially by Qype and the Hawksmoor crew, aimed squarely at showing us what they can offer, and unabashedly at getting some decent online reviews out of it, the wheels of which intention they oiled extremely well by watering us for free all evening. We were treated to a semi-private room off to the side from the main restaurant, a lowly-lit and richly-upholstered platform which managed to seem intimate while still seating a maximum 12 or so. Cocktails were the early order of service and the list was so extensive that I simply gave up and asked for "something with Hendricks gin in it", a slightly feeble cop-out that was nonetheless met with a smile and, in time, a really bloody good cocktail - perhaps predictably featuring mint and cucumber, but matched delightfully with the spirit, allowing a hint of bite, but still smooth as you like. (Well, smooth as I like, which is "very smooth indeed"). A bottle of Ramón Bilbao 2007 Rioja was decanted in preparation for the meal and we made our selections from the menu whose categories took in "Steaks", "Sides", and "The rest", with the latter designation including the excellently opaque "Vegetarian". That's what you're getting, vegetarian, like it or lump it. Quite a variety of fish and seafood adorned the collection of starters but of course I'd have none of it, and headed straight for the Tamworth belly ribs, which turned out to be quite a smart move. Succulent, tender pork was served on the bone with a chili and honey-glazed sauce lending a gentle tang to offset what might otherwise have been seen as slightly under-crisped belly fat but which, in the combination presented, worked well, the rib meat and the browned sauce adding texture and the fat bringing yet further moisture and flavour to the party. The recent late flowering of sunny days meant that we were able to get hold of what must surely have been one of the last few jugs of Hawksmoor Summer Punch served this year, a concoction of strawberry and some mysterious sort of magic that seemed to be switching off sections of my brain at a rattling pace, prompting me to switch in turn to the Rioja after only a few glasses, for fear of doing something ridiculous without even knowing it. The wine was a Tempranillo and Garnacha blend, rich and quite bold but not too shouty, and it flowed happily all through the meal. For the main course two of my companions and I opted to share a 950-gramme porterhouse steak, which I went for largely because I'd never had one before - only to discover that it's very similar to a T-bone, just cut more from the rear end of the short loin and so comprising more tenderloin meat. Suits me. 950 grammes is a lot of steak, even if the bone apparently takes up 50-70 grammes, and split between 3 of us it was a decent 10oz steak each, served sliced and, at our host's suggestion, medium rare, which turned out in Hawksmoor terminology still to be a nice dark rich purply red inside a properly charred exterior. This was excellent steak. No sauce, no pretension, just a little crystal sea-salt which brought the meat's flavour even further out. A confident, rich flavour, the charring unable to overpower the long, full beefy tone. The Hawksmoor's association with the Ginger Pig is a fruitful one, and they know what they're doing with what they get. We ordered some side salads that strangely no-one seemed too fussed about, but the tomato was noteworthy, fresh and tasting slightly of sunlight like the best ones do. The chips were OK, not exactly lacklustre but could have been a bit crisper and a bit hotter; the potato gratin, on the other hand, was killer. Dessert was for me an obvious choice - a cheese platter consisting of cheddar, soft blue and some mild goat, washed down with a half-bottle of spicy Dixon's 10-year tawny port between 4 of us. This would realistically have been quite enough, but as I was surrounded by people who'd ordered the most amazing chocolate brownie glories which they weren't quite able to polish off, I had to dive in and help out. Obviously. So all round, this was a great evening at Hawksmoor: low-key but stylish surroundings, an array of superb meat, friendly and accommodating staff plying us with booze all the way through, and when I go back, I reckon I'll be piling in to the ribeye and the Chateaubriand. I notice that other reviews have made much of the apparently high drinks prices; while I can't really comment on them as I was fortunate enough not to have to pay them much attention, the food was by no means cheap, but it was fairly

sRMW_Pm7skHmG75uHafeDA.text: Love this place. Best steak I've had and a great cocktail list. It's not cheap but if you're looking for a place to splash the cash and like steak and/or cocktails, Hawksmoor should certainly be considered.

fLwfptMGIJAH1sr4dr8U5g.text: The 2 of us decided to treat ourselves@ Hawksmoor Spitalfields on a recommendation from a friend that told us this place was amazingWe ended up leaving the restaurant very disappointed in the whole experience.The service by Rachele was very cold from the very start, and there was no personalised service at all. We almost felt like it was a inconvenience for us to be there. (no smiles, or no explanation of the steak menu at all. All she told us about the menu was that they had run out of the ribs) The restaurant was so noisy by a few drunks on our next table shouting at eachother that we could barely hear ourselves thinkWe found a hair in the wine, and the Rib-eye steak 400g which cost £28 each probably had about a 100g worth of fat that i trimmed off it, and the mushroom sauce was luke warm. To be honest the best part of the meal was the side order of mushrooms. For the 2 fatty steaks, 1 glass of wine, 1 bottle of water, 1 small pot of chips, and a dish of mushrooms came to £86.00 Rachele tried to charge us for an extra 2 cocktails on our bill we didn't order with the 1st bill TOTALLING £114They had the cheek to charge us £9.63 service charge without asking us (the service was supposed to be 'optional')To finish it off, we were completely ignored at the reception area on the way out too.I'm amazed this place has so many good reviews.For me it was just a average overpriced steak, with poor service and the whole experience left me with a bitter taste in my mouth.Maybe we caught the Hawksmoor on a bad day, buti would never return here, or recommend to friends.

9S3dGkEt0G0MUkmLOVSrBA.text: It was my first trip to London and I was dying to try a traditional English breakfast.. The Hawksmoor delivered and more.  The meal was amazing, a little intense for my girlfriend, but I loved it!  How can you not love a meal that includes a smoked bacon chop??  The service was great, our waiter was extremely helpful and recommended the #7 bloody mary, which was the perfect compliment to the meal.  If I'm ever back in London, I will definitely be back.  We also really enjoyed the Spitalsfield location and probably wouldn't have visited that area if it weren't for the restaurant.

49CloACZeJj-1N1pxCTtzg.text: I agree with ricard. The food here is great but it is so expensive and I do feel it is over priced for what you get. The likes of Jay Rayner love it, but then wouldn't anyone if they could put every meal they eat on their expenses? For the price, the service you get is not very amazing. I would rather buy some steaks from the Ginger Pig and cook them myself.

HUp5GJfn_DuChtx5kV_uAQ.text: This place has some of the best cocktails you will find.  Arrive early to get to the bar, stay late to work your way through the list and ask the barmen what they've got new and special just now.  Oh, and eat . . . if you get hungry.

V5GrLZmqDHjAqUhptDtHyQ.text: Best steak I've ever had! By far the best in London. Don't anyone dare mention gaucho in comparison, if you are a meat and cocktail fan then visit this restaurant.

nJ1kwSTRaIie6WI1Ei_5AA.text: The ratings I'm giving shouldn't be taken to read that this restaurant is average. It's actually a very pleasurable experience, but you pay fine dining prices for it. The wine list is very good, but the prices are absurdly inflated, and there are very few wines under £50 worth having. It's abusive, frankly, and if restaurants seriously believe that diners aren't aware of this, they are living in a vacuum. However, the meat is tremendous. I doubt there's a better steak in London. The cuts are all from the Ginger Pig, so the origin is flawless. I had a monster sirloin which was pure hedonism and carnivorous sensuality. Lots of noise, atmosphere and fun, and typical London service - i.e. nothing special. Good, but stupidly pricey. For this money I can feed exactly the same food and wine to four times the number of people, in my own home. 8 October 2009 update: Hawskmoor have kindly approached me about this review today via Twitter. It is very gratifying when establishments show they care about their reputation by engaging directly with their customers. They said that "wine and steak in particular are good value" with "much lower mark-ups than most places." I will give the Hawksmoor another go as a result. Lots of people love it and that must be for a reason. I won't amend my original review, because it reflects the experience I had, but I will say this: a place that listens to feedback and takes it seriously deserves respect, and a second chance. I look forward to another steak!

wCOeqS9wK8Wjlv3Th3GHJA.text: The steaks are undeniable good and cooked to perfection.But be warned that the cost of all the 'extras' like triple fried chips, mushrooms etc can quickly mount up and present you with a nasty shock when you receive the final bill. Budget for £50-60 per head with moderate wine.

h0PXbbZ9Ob3Kw9IxI6Z8pw.text: Delicious!!! I love this place. The best steak in town! My favourite dessert in town (salted caramel ice cream with shortbread). They have a great thing going here.

FlwRSzGFX9CREKMEjqtBjA.text: great cocktail list. had the fancy gin cocktail. delicious. skipped the starters and went right to the meat and sides. wasn't disappointed. rib eye and porterhouse both solid. sides were decent, mac and cheese better than the mushrooms, creamed spinach and triple cooked chips. sticky toffee pudding and a coffee with baileys closed out a high quality meal.

dCB5jZacUirUDhGRP36YHQ.text: The chicken here was so good, and it was not too expensive.  And the drinks were great!  The decor is nice.  This place is really special.

cAFFTDW-PWAuyp9zeQ53aA.text: II think most things have been said about how amazing this place is so will keep this short.The steaks are simply the best I have tried in The UK this place was actually recommend by a Chef I know at a Ramsey resturant and guess you don't get a better recommendation then that!Always a great atmosphere and is now open Sunday Daytimes so I go almost every week, They also do a Sunday Beef Roast with all the usual for a daft £10 and if your looking for amazing value then that is just Bargain of the Year.Me I go for steak and they are the tastiest always perfectly cooked with great service and atmosphere the only place on Par overseas Del Frescos in New York Or Vegas but after travelling the world several times and having every kind of cow in every country you can imagine this place is simply fantastic.

GImUujK4qUrtoPy_kuAhDg.text: I want to start this review with 'Hawksmoor is basically London's best steakhouse' and it is. My first venture to the Covent Garden branch was wonderful  darkly lit decadence filled with a muted roar of deep chatter, amazing steak and buttered carrots. The second venture to Hawksmoor was to the slightly more hall-like Guidhall (Bank). Both were for dinner, and both splenddid. But after brunch at Spitalfields I can away with a feeling of 'rather good'. I suspect the problem was that I expected more from the dinners they're famed for. True, the East London brand set up is more mellow. The brunches, served in the windowless bar downstairs  perfect for a hangover  are American styled. And it's impossible not to order a cocktail (Marmalade  amazing). We had Hot Dogs, a Burger, and got excited over the sides, with chicken wings, fries (perhaps worth going for these alone, honestly) and spare-rib nuggets (deep-fat fried spare rib meat). 50% of the food I loved and would give 5 stars to, the other half I'd give a lower grade, and that's what let it down  just a few touches. First class presentation, I didn't leave feeling that I'd had the best hot dog of my life. Actually, I found myself picking around the slightly odd caremalised onions to where the sausage was. Once I had, it was very tasty but the extra bits of beautiful presentation weren't that tasty (e.g. cute mustard and ketchup but no warning to say 'No Thanks!'). It was lovely, wonderful, but a little ordinary for what I expect from Hawksmoor. I'd have left a little unhappier had it not been during the soft launch. Opt for Seven Dials for dinner instead.

OuL5JXzdNaCUMBYRNkrwQg.text: An absolutely amazing experience from start to finish. The food was some of the best I've ever had in London and the drinks were out of this world. I think I might fly back just to have dinner again! The servers were outstanding - we were especially impressed by their knowledge of the menu. The meat melted in your mouth, the side dishes were divine, and the drinks, oh the drinks, some of the best cocktails I've ever had. Don't miss Hawksmoor the next time you're in London!

-cFQNwWhuw-y2gAk3pbMFQ.text: better than Gaucho's. but not the best steak i've had. i wish they told me beforehand that my steak would be cut up before served. regardless of the pre-cutting it was still cooked perfectly medium rare. Even despite my request for it rare, their recommendation of the rib eye medium rare was surpringly a good one.

eADs5PZjBs4KHezhCzMoKA.text: I just went here for lunch with 4 friends. Having eaten dinner here before, i knew it would be good eats. As predicted, the food was delicious; no doubt about it. But we arrived at 11:10am, and didn't receive our brunch until 12:30pm. We were the only customers during the majority of that time, and we didn't order anything complicated. Our waiter provided terrible service, and fortunately for him, I didn't catch his name. He was unfamiliar with his menu - we often had to point items out after he'd tell us he didn't know what we were asking for - and he was incredibly slow with delivery. Our appetizer, oysters, arrived 45 minutes later with one oyster fork for the 5 of us to share. My beer that I ordered before my meal arrived during my final bites. It took him about 30 minutes to come back to our table post-ordering to tell us that one of the items was out. Definitely an unnecessary delay. He never checked in or asked us how things were going. We had to be completely proactive with him. When we left, we told the hostess that we had had some problems with service, and made a joke that perhaps he was hungover and needed a coffee. Rather than be professional, she joked that they were all moving slowly today. Ridiculous. Amazing food is no excuse for horrendous service. It was an embarrassing showing, and I won't be back.

FdOgIn7OtX9oca6zs3yJ4w.text: For photos see Greedy Diva @ greedydiva.blogspot.com/…  "We almost didn't put that on the menu - we thought "who'd have steak and half a lobster for breakfast?"" Will, co-owner of Hawksmoor, and I looked over in unison at TPG, a man up to his elbows in rib eye and lobster meat. There's always one in every crowd. Hawksmoor is a steak house in East London famed for serving up great quality British beef, grilled on charcoal to blissful perfection. All meat is sourced from the Ginger Pig, and steaks are, patriotically, from Longhorn cattle, reared in Yorkshire and aged for around 35 days. On Saturday, we were there to test out the first trial run of Hawksmoor's new breakfast menu. Thus, the need for TPG to conduct a comprehensive investigation of the hefty surf 'n turf option. The weekend brunch menu revolves around quality meat products and bears the usual array of Hawksmoor's staples - the steaks, the infamous burger - and some fabulous new additions such as my Sausage and Egg HK Muffin (£8) or (for £30) the full English for two - comprising a bone-in bacon chop, sausages (pork, beef and mutton), short rib bubble 'n squeak, grilled bone marrow, trotter baked beans, Bury black pudding, roast tomatoes, grilled mushrooms and endless thick slices of dripping toast... all with an onion and bone marrow gravy. The HK muffin had wooed me from afar, practically wolf whistling from across the room on someone else's plate. It tasted as good as it looked. Two runny fried eggs are piled into a lovely thick grilled muffin bun with a spicy flat sausage made from pork, beef and mutton, all topped with Ogleshield cheese. The only slightest critique I can offer is that the sausage was slightly too "spiced up" for me. I added Ginger Pig bacon, which is the closest thing I've had to the best of Australia's mouthwatering bacon in this country. TPG's steak was so sublime it made us seriously weak at the knees. Perfection. He had it medium, as recommended by our helpful waitress for the rib eye cut, to really get the fatty marbling melting through the meat. If you're a steak and eggs man, this one's for you. TPG saddled it up decadently with a half lobster (add 12 quid), which was slightly overcooked and rubbery. Still, nothing could detract from our adoration of the rest of his plate. We teamed up our selections with some of HK's renowed fabulous drinks. I was feeling fiesty so opted for the Bloody Mary #10 - made with a refreshing cucumber hit and the bite of horseradish. Loved it! TPG, predictably, could not go past the cornflake milk milkshake. That's right folks - the cornflakes are soaked in milk overnight, drained (there are no "bits" in it) and then the milk is used to make the ice cream for what is undoubtedly THE BEST FLAVOURED MILKSHAKE in the entire universe. It's even knocked Shake Shack's salted caramel from the top of the perch. This seems to be some variation on similar shakes offered at my beloved Momofuku Bakery in New York - an ingenious addition to the breakfast menu. We eventually retired, content and bellies full, to the bar to watch the masterful hands of Shaky Pete at work. Pete is not only super friendly, but a cocktail guru. He whipped me up a refreshing ginger brew in no time - ginger, lemon, beer and other secret ingredients giving it a sassy sorbet texture. It's like the best shandy you've ever imagined. Highly recommended. TPG obviously felt he needed to show his sophisticated side after the milk shake, and chose a superb armagnac. Layers of chocolate, toffee and other delights wafted up to the nose and romanced the palate. Gorgeous. We are hunting down a bottle for home (if only TPG had not washed since he wrote the name on his hand). Pricing on the new day time menu seems fair. It's not a dirt cheap breakfast, but you're getting top quality ingredients, perfectly executed at a very reasonable price. It's good value. Even better was the pricing on Saturday since we were trialling the menu at a 50% discount to allow any kinks to be ironed out before the official launch this week on 13th March (although I've quoted the full prices here). The worst thing about the new weekend brunch menu is the complete inability to decide what to have - what can't you live without? Other new lunch options include the roast beef (roasted on charcoal and finished in the oven to achieve that "roasted on a spit flavour") with dripping roast potatoes, Yorkshire pudding, carrots, greens and bone marrow & onion gravy. My stomach just rumbled while typing. And, of course, there's the Hawksmoor burger. We had devoured one recently (Valentines Day doesn't get more romantic than this) and it certainly lives up to its reputation. Gloopy, loosely packed meat from Longhorn cattle (a range of cuts) is enriched by globs of fatty bone marrow in the mix. A simple salad, pickles, mustard mayo and simple brioche bun are, idyllicly, the only distractions from the main game. On this

g8hODzEzXDQZgoYbe8CafQ.text: This review is Hawksmoor Spitalfields and specifically to the bar down a stairs. Now I know Hawksmoor is known for its steak. Looking Hawksmoor up online or with the knowledge of its book out you'd know they steak like the back of their hand. They pretty much rule the meat world in London. So much so most e-chefs use the 'ex-Hawksmoor chef' line in any bio.Downstairs is beautiful lair which has an array of truly excellent cocktails. My favourite is Ginger Pete's Shaky Brew. It's London Pride mixed with Ginger Beer and sorts. It's so damn addictive and tasty. The other thing you should be trying while sipping on this is some chips, some ox cheek nuggets (with some incredible kimchi sauce to dip)as well as some chicken wings.The main event will always be the thing voted top 10 small eats in London. The French Shortrib ox cheek bun. With a gravy boat to dip into. This is my guilty pleasure. This is my top sinful eat in London. If I want to take a friend or two to impress or dine and get drunk and have fun times. I will go back for more and more. As long as I continue to do my fitness so my waistline doesn't expand too much! This is a must go to in London.

PoD-i3wBqhh0KnOXT6GfEA.text: My god, the food is worth every penny you spend here.I have been waiting for ages to have Sunday Lunch at Hawksmoor (Due to family commitments etc etc) and finally during half term (as I hadn't been to the Spitalfields branch yet) I managed to book and eat there. All I can say is that this is the type of meal that stays in your mind days after you had it. I can still taste the pink beef, massive Yorkie's, fluffy but crispy roast potatoes... I still drool thinking about it and all this for £20. I did have other bits and pieces (My staples being the Bone Marrow and Scallops- make sure YOU order these every time too!!), but the roast itself is only £20 and as I said in the beginning, worth every single penny!You will have to wait a bit for the Sunday Roast (15-20min approx), but that is due to the dish being made fresh for you (and I guess to rest the meat).Service was swift and unobtrusive (Paula, thank you). Ambience is lively, but I won't say loud.Overall, make the effort to go and eat there- The food is the star attraction and your taste buds will thank you for it.

b88RcS19jnJSA25QUdA01Q.text: We have been here twice. Both times we dropped in ad hoc and had burgers and fries downstairs in the bar area. We once also had the cheesecake. Everything in the Hawksmoor is excellent. After trying burgers in many parts of London, this is definitely still our favourite.

UHsJ0HFwx67_voDeJnKxeA.text: "Sir, the porterhouse is quite big and is usually shared""I'll manage it, can I have lobster and bone marrow on the side please"I came here to cheer myself up after spending eight hours in an austrian airport only to get turned back after a flight cancellation. Well cheer me up this did - after the above food and a butter infused old fashioned (and a bottle of wine) I was ready to take on the world.Staff were attentive (as a solo diner often you end up being ignored) and willing to have a conversation and my night was made much better because of this. Will come again next time I need a pick me up!

agyd68d5YuNPdx7XmU3DbA.text: We sat in the basement bar, and I found the drinks and food to be pretty reasonable. I had a french dip, which didn't come with au jus, surprisingly. Isn't that, like, the french dip's thing?Anyway, had great service all night and when an order got missed it was fixed very quickly and with sincere apologies. My only issue was the grease hanging in the air and the stuffiness. Put a kitchen in a basement without any windows/circulation and you get a very gross environment. I left feeling like a had a film on me :/ But I would definitely recommend a post-work drink and dinner here if you want a good piece of grilled meat without the big cost

7vSxyVN4KqvSjggGZtcbxQ.text: I finally had an excuse to come here.It's a bit more than I would usually pay for a meal out. The starters average around £12 each, the house bottle of wine is £25, the fillet steak is £34 for 200grams. However, the food is all wonderful.I enjoyed every course and every side and the steak was cooked absolutely perfectly. There is a good ambiance in the restaurant and the service was attentive and friendly. The staff knew the menu very well and, although of course they were mostly upselling, a lot of their suggestions were helpful.In short everything was delicious. I'm just sad that it has to remain a rare treat!

HQBaTL8-OgueDGCDuSleOg.text: Great restaurant, same as the other ones though. In terms of interior, I still think the Covent Garden one is the best, but the food is of course still great here!The bar downstairs is great too for things like quick lunches and brunch....

IWJ-2mK7RzcwkxiTlSg78g.text: I've been wanting to come here for a while now as i have heard good review after good review, but i didn't come here for the steak, oh no no no the burger was at the top of my want list.The bacon cheese burger arrived on our table and i was like a kid in a candy store, the bun was fluffy and light, the meat tender and juicy, each bite was meet with a groan , it was food porn, the triple cooked chips were really nice to, and went well with the Hawksmoor homemade ketchup. The wife had the beef roast and she claimed it was the best roast dinner she has ever had, and that's saying a lot. So onto the staff, the staff were all very friendly and looked after us pretty well, so all in all our Hawksmoor experience was a good one.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Hawks
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. The Hawksmoor Burger.

g5WqpAQhClIasUiFkedIIQ.text: Incredible meal and easily one of the best steaks I've ever had. We went for the Porterhouse and it arrived at the table cooked to perfection. The sides complimented it perfectly especially the bone marrow gravy.  The in house sommelier was invaluable in helping to select the right wine and was surprisingly was just as enthusiastic about some of the less expensive bottles.

laM8yoT0EcvBeXtgdtIVIA.text: The ambience here is great - the bar is quiet enough for conversation yet funky enough to enjoy drinks.I went for the Ox cheeky nuggets (cooked to perfection and worth a try) and the cheeseburger. The quality of the meat shines through immediately. The triple cooked chips were also good, extra crunchy too.Overall a great experience!

f-exCSd0PgyhrI8SmuY-dw.text: Having been to another Hawskmoor, this one was even better. I came here for dinner and think the staff thought I was waiting form someone as after 45 minutes, I had to ask to be server.Despite this, I had my usual, rare fillet steak with sides, definitely the best steak i think I have ever had. It was lean, tasty and melted in my mouth. I highly recommend this restaurant. The staff were friendly and service was very good after the initial challenge. It is pricey, but reflects the quality of service and food.

8BYjgSSjJCy3CF3gKVKL3g.text: Forget the steak! I would happily come here just for a scoop of the Cornflake and the popcorn ice cream!We booked a table for 6.30 and walked in to a relatively empty restaurant. The wine list was quite extensive and we opted for a Merlot which was quite sharp but went well with the food. As the restaurant filled up I ordered the rib eye medium rare and was told that it had a bit of fat, but had a lot of flavour. The other half ordered the fillet blue. We also got sides of creamed spinach, buttered greens, and mac n cheese.My steak was ok. It was very sinewy and I found it quite hard to cut at times. Next time I will order the fillet as my other half had a gorgeous piece of meat which melted in your mouth. The creamed spinach was amazing, and the buttered greens were nice. The mac n cheese was not the best I've had.. but it was a good try. I almost opted out of a dessert, but the BF insisted we have one because he knows how much I LOVE ice cream. We got a scoop of the popcorn and a scoop of the cornflake. And wow! just wow. Forget the steaks I'm coming for the ice cream next time.

K78768fYWDvZII85AXMNuQ.text: I liked this place, but I thought it was pretty expensive for what it was. The menu is fairly limited, but what they do, they do very well. The food was delicious and the portions were ample enough. The service wasn't great; I asked the waiter 3 times for my glass of wine before I just got up and went to order at the bar. That said, another waiter did help me out with deciphering which options on the menu would suit me as a wheat-free option, so thanks for that sonny.

dIzav0dl8LscdyGbY2g_sg.text: There are many "poutine" hits on Yelp, but only the Hawksmoor delivered. When you click on the Hawksmoor, you can actually find a poutine review whereas a random selection of other restaurant hits bring such poor results.Enough about my Yelp complaints. The Hawksmoor has several restaurants in the area and many menus. I was having trouble finding poutine proof until a FB inquiry proved fruitful. The Spitalfield location has two kitchens so be sure to go downstairs for the poutine.The bar menu has a small selection of Food, Sides (poutine and more), Puddings, and Cocktails. I ordered the oxtail poutine and the Hong Kong Phooey Reloaded. I'm a sucker for peer pressure. Why else would I have a cocktail that blends 7 different spirits and tastes like vitamin water. Evil deceptive creature. My friend ordered the triple cooked chips, Marmalade Cocktail, and the chili cheese dog.Everyone was happy. The oxtail poutine was delicious. I was hoping for cheese curds, but at least there was some cheese. The focus clearly was on the savory and spicy oxtail soaking the chips with its delicious juices. In the end, I was using triple cooked chips to clean the iron dish spotless. And the chilli cheese dog delighted my friend. She especially enjoyed the cheese on this hearty dish. i definitely recommend this place.

CGCRvzXrBy4a3k-ezdyAEA.text: Honestly, one of the best steaks I've had anywhere... pricey, but perfectly done (consistently) and those chips... oh, those triple cooked chips!I've been to a few of their other locations, but this is the one with the most character, in my opinion, and I believe it is the original one... it has a rustic yet fancy feel, but not too imposing compared to similar establishments. To me the best way to enjoy this place is to come with a friend, or a few friends, and get a big ole honkin' steak to share if you're in the same mind as to prep, cut, etc. Last time I went was with about four other people and we split one large steak, by weight off of the board, ordered a smaller one of a different cut,  and a few sides... absolutely divine. The service is attentive and friendly, fitting for the atmosphere, and it has a fun bar with interesting cocktails (The Shaky Pete's Ginger Brew is a must try, the rumours are true) for those dining upstairs.The only thing I would say is that if you're not a steak person then obviously this may not be the place for you... they have other options, but steak is what they're rightfully known for so if you're a steak lover feeling like a splurge give it a go!Make sure you check out the downstairs bar if you're in the mood for something different and more relaxed, it has a few overlapping things on the menu such as the Shaky Pete's and those triple cooked chips... oh, those chips (have I mentioned the chips?), but the downstairs has a completely different feel and menu. Unfortunately you cannot cross order from the menus, so if you want a gorgeous steak then upstairs is the only option, etc., but definitely check out the reviews for the downstairs bar... if the upstairs doesn't float your boat then the downstairs may be just the ticket. Unless something had changed drastically you really need to book here, but it's worth it.

ntWilKutS5DcQNUT4z4jHA.text: This is one of my go to places for Sunday lunch.Food is obviously incredible (I wouldn't write a review just for that. Everyone else has that covered). My main qualm with this place, which is also it's usp I guess, is that they only do beef... Keeps me from coming back as it's the same meal repeatedly. That said, if you're in the mood for roast beef, or have never been here, go here. Then go enjoy a hipster beer somewhere in shoreditch.Dress code - well I feel like you should make some effort. But bear in mind that next to a hipster in a Hawaiian shirt, shorts and a monocle, anyone looks dressy... But also square.

aI8XI5j4Z_oh8iVjJLgd-w.text: It's too easy to exclaim, HawksMOAR!!!Well that IS the only way to sum it up; if I had a little bit o extra cash in my pocket I would come here every Friday eves to enjoy a bit o' meat and a bit o' artery cloggage. The waiter was fantastic in terms of food/wine knowledge as well as physical presentation (hot damn) and we splurged on an 800g porterhouse of pure winning and a nice California shirazMedium rare  + a glug o bernaise + mashed tates and gravy + RIBS TO START + mac and cheese (I should'ved - the mac and cheese...very rich and proved to be an unnecessary accessory towards shortened lifespan) = an amazing meal.  The underground meat dungeon-esque vibe also lent to quite a few hilarious discussions that were definitely not for the faint hearted, or religious. Try to ignore the host/hostess staff (I do try very hard to do this at most 'ditch places) - they couldn't find my name on the computer screen for about 5 minutes...until I peeked over and pointed it out to them.  Literacy has to be a requirement for jobs in London, right? (??)Another slight negative point involved my friend experiencing the runs afterward, but I think it was just his stomach not being used to unprocessed food.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. I had to put my head down on the table after ingesting this spectacle of a steak.

2Tr9VkEFxg_GINdNejK44Q.text: Filet with grilled bone marrow on top with a side of anchovy Hollandaise was legitimately the best steak I have ever had. Server was impeccable. Price was expensive but fair for the quality. We absolutely return anytime I'm in London.

v_QVCfOFSTH-KQwEEPeJ3Q.text: I've only ever eaten downstairs in the bar as opposed to the main restaurant. Don't make the mistake of going to the right hand door if you only want the bar; I suffered the tongue of a snooty man when I did!It's a real casual affair downstairs but the decor, atmosphere and staff are spot on. I've only been in a group of two or three and when it's not so busy they allow you to sit where you want. They have 3 huge booths that sit around 10 people which I choose to avoid as I'd rather not be that inconsiderate group talking up too much space!The bar menu is naturally shorter than the main restaurant with a focus on finger foods. For starters I had the ox cheek nuggets; fried nuggets that are oozing with cheese and ox cheek meat. They're so tasty and are accompanied by a tomato based dip that has a tiny edge of spice to it. The pork ribs are immense with soft meat that falls away from the bone with complete ease, you get a good amount for a starter and the marinade they're covered in is the right side of sweet.For main, the cheeseburger is a great choice especially when having it pink as it just tastes amazing. Soft enough to fall apart in your mouth but firm enough to be eaten cleanly without it disintegrating in your hands after a few bites (pet hate with some burgers and their buns).The bar itself has a great selection of drinks on hand; the food menu features a selection of classics and their occasional special cocktails but should you not see something on there, the team usually seem happy enough to knock up a cocktail for you.To top it all off, the staff are a lovely bunch of friendly people with a sense of humour to boot; they make their job seem so effortless and always have a smile on their face. Definitely worth a visit if you get the chance.

E_3CcIGDIb3-0xPTX45RhQ.text: I'm fond of beef - it's no secret. The juicier and more tender, the better. And when I'm paying premium rates, size -does- matter.Thanks to Haley F for organising Steak Night 2.0, I had an excuse to stuff my face with some superlative slabs of meat at the Hawksmoor. Similar to their exceptional Sunday roast, the bovine remains they have on offer are executed superbly. As are the cocktails on their drinks menu.Admittedly, the experience here would have been dramatically improved had our server not been quite as much of a dominatrix. Though she wasn't sporting fishnet stockings, high-heel boots, or wielding a riding crop, her demeanour was pretty much what I'd expect from a woman who brooks no backtalk and knows what's good for you, even if you don't necessarily agree.My recommendation is to go heavy on the sides. You can't go wrong. The thrice-cooked chips are salted to perfection and crisped to an ideal consistency, the creamed spinach is satisfyingly decadent, and the cheesy mac comes in a cast-iron skillet with plenty of crunchy bits for all.All told, for a drink or two, a filling portion of rib-eye, and a sampling of sides, the per head cost ran about £60. Not affordable by any means, but quite commensurate to both quality and value. The Hawksmoor is certainly worthy of a return visit - hopefully with a server that's somewhat less domineering and when there isn't a drunktastic birthday party going on at the table just next to us!

6uLV8h77Sgf9P2wAd4jDAQ.text: I've always had suggestions to try Hawksmoor because I would "love it". Now, I'm very skeptical about things and don't like a big up before I try something. I'm religious but I still want to see with my own eyes Jesus walking on water and also making a blind man see.If Hawksmoor is able to make me believe in one thing though it is that their food is my definition of Food Heaven .... **In a dreamy voice** - Lobster!From the starters such as the Scallops to the tender mouth watering Steak (when I say mouth watering I truly and heart heavily mean it) to the Mac and Cheese and the Lobster ! Now, I love food but I watch what I eat but I failed big time here. BIG Time! I was in a meeting and the client barely heard a word from me. Thank God I had a Scottish colleague who talked a lot. I don't remember having desserts but they did give us some complimentary chocolates to accompany the chilled and smooth texture of the Coffee Martini. Coffee + chocolate + Alcohol = Darn it, I'm an addict. Oh, I nearly forgot about the lovely staff! They were very attentive during my visit even though I feel slightly embarrassed about the clean plates ... Not. I'm sorry, not sorry.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Mac and cheese
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Surf and turf
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom

jJyfl_o6W2vzGBUkgr3OTA.text: I've been looking forward to visiting Hawksmoor for a very long time and this is not any old Hawksmoor this is the original in Spitalfields. A pleasant concierge greeted us and quickly showed us to our, un-reserved, seats. It was a quiet Bank Holiday Monday so assume to book in advance to be guaranteed a seat.The restaurant was fairly busy with a mixture of customers. Seemingly a good date venue, for men looking to splash some cash but equally welcoming of larger groups and families.The decor, to be honest looked a little dated. Not worn but dated. An old fashioned vibe, which I like, but an un-natural, tried, environment (Soho House do it better).The menu was simple and, obviously, meat-centric (which is no bad thing). We opted to stick to the menu rather than go for the specials on the board, which is something I now regret. I started with the Hawksmoor smoked Salmon. At £15 it was nothing to blow my mind. A small portion of fish with some soda bread and salad. Main coarse was the filet steak, 300g. I chose mine rare, which is how I always prefer my steak cooked but, again, in this instance something I now regret. A tasty enough cut of meat, overly salted and with an almost mushy texture. My expectation, of the best steak in London, was sadly not met on this occasion. The meal with wine was £72pp. For me the experience and food didn't live up to the billing and certainly not to the price. I'd go again, for sure but this time with the specials board on the agenda. This is definitely the type of place where to have a good time you need to go all in (£££).

Bl_D2FkbjTLprLSZFwEV0A.text: I have finally giving a five star and it has been a long time coming. Firstly I could of have giving this review the first time I came here a few years ago but I deliberately held out until I have giving this place another visit which would lead me to a more balance review.  So let's talk about the service. It was truly great as it was not only my wife's birthday but also our anniversary (yes I the same day!) meaning it was a big day for us. It started with the phone call to book a table for two and the moment I have them my name they said, "hey your already on our system, can we confirm your address and number is..." This made a good impression straight away as not only they kept my personal details but they also knew why we came the first time and they said they will prepare a nice dessert which ended up being on the house.  The location is one of those places you don't even have to try, you will just miss it as it is a dark black building with only the resturant name above the door and if you do glimpse in you would be excuse for thinking it is a pub or posh pub with a couple of tables. Now the food was a top standard throughout even when they brought my medium rare sirloin steak rare, there was no fuss or issues they just took it away and cooked it again exactly how I liked. Even when the wife thought the cream spinach was not great once again they said don't worry about it, it is off the bill. The waiter was absolutely fantastic to the point of sitting down and going through our options with us and spending that quality time to help create that environment that we enjoyed. As mentioned earlier on, the dessert for both of us was on the house and it was a real nice touch that they decorated the plates to signify our double celebration and to be honest the plate decor was all I was expecting as they said on the phone when I was booking they would do that, so we were both nicely surprised. I love coming here, you don't feel rushed or pressured. It is a very relaxed chilled out atmosphere and I know we will surely be back here!

Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. An array of food #hawsmoor #weddinganniversary #birthdaylunch #foodie #dishes
