kt130oBBNzBPOqk0szxqyA.text: It's been a while since I've made it here even though I used to work close by.  Reputed to have the best steak in London I've always wanted to try Hawksmoor and what better one than the original. On a busy night, service was pretty good, fast and friendly despite the number of tables each waiter had to cover.  It's a nice restaurant where everything seems to work which creates a nice overall steak restaurant vibe.  We decided to dive straight into mains with loads of sides: A 1kg Porterhouse, 1 Lobster, bone marrow, chips, jersey royals, macaroni cheese, creamed spinach, mushrooms, and bearnaise sauce. The lobster had a nice garlic butter sauce and was a pretty good size for a native.  The bone marrow was a pretty generous portion too although dry and salty (some pieces had no marrow).  As we delved into more of the food it was apparent the chefs like their salt here.  The steak was especially salty - borderline of being inedible.  The sides were good though, in fact all the sides were good.But more than just being salty the fillet side of the Porterhouse was horrible: mushy and it had an old after-taste to it.  They did quickly rectify this and we were brought another Porterhouse in 5 minutes which was much better, not easy to do during a busy service.  Though still over salted the meat texture was correct as were the natural meat flavours that struggled to break through the heavy seasoning. We were kindly offered free desserts, but we were stuffed so a bottle of red was on the house.  It was unfortunate our first steak was bad, but they did give us another one without argument and I can understand that it's not totally possible to taste each steak that goes out. But even ignoring that first steak, the over seasoning is a bit of an issue.  Was it the best steak I've had in a London restaurant?  That award still goes to Maze Grill, maybe Maze got lucky that time and I just happened to get an amazing piece of meat that was packed full of fresh meaty flavour and perfectly cooked. They say you should never meet your heroes, you'll only be disappointed.  Maybe the hype killed it for me, but it has a reputation for a reason.  Unfortunately Hawksmoor was only good at best, with many steaks being at least equal to the one I had at their original restaurant.

5IUaXsVN8fEaLRiWTDbtNw.text: Pricey but so tasty. I had the petit fillet and it was seasoned and cooked to perfection. For starters we shared some of the scallops which were good but not great. I'd recommend skipping the starter and just save room for your main. And book ahead - you'll need it.

FA-h0wghMKct8yOxB29oCQ.text: Visited as part of a stag do (early on so as to not be obnoxious!) and was very impressed with the quality of meats and the level of service.  We weren't causing scenes like you hear about stag do's doing, however we were feeling a good buzz upon arrival. The waiter could surely tell, but was completely professional and did his job while letting us have fun.I shared one of the larger cuts and found it to be cooked to perfection, with just the right balance between tenderness and doneness.  The bernaise sauce on the side put it over the top; it's amazing how quickly 450g (ok, some of it was bone...) can disappear in such a short span.Would recommend out for a special treat or just a really good steak!

IIO6dLERatUOqPy3nlFqUw.text: Great restaurant, solid menu, excellent food, great bar and drink menu.   Even the wait staff is helpful and down to earth.   Homey atmosphere all around good place. By far the best restaurant  I visited in my last London trip.

3jQ3p5AP2zybiEs8v6CcsQ.text: My husband and I went for dinner here as a post wedding treat so we thought we'd go the whole hog and order what we liked and we liked what we ordered!Firstly, in case you don't want to read my essay, BOOKING IS ESSENTIAL!The food here is very nice and we shared a piece of juicy perfectly cooked chateaubriand with mac'n'cheese and triple cooked fries. MmMmMmmmm!The decor is nice, quite dark and intimate, and what seems to be standard steak restaurant fair at the moment.So three stars then? Well, the place is a posh restaurant masquerading as a chilled place to dine and you can feel it! The staff try to be casual in their brushed cotton checked shirts while waving wine lists worthy of Mayfair restaurants under your nose. It's probably the close proximity to the city but great steak does not have to come with wine at £60+ a bottle and there is a very limited number of wines served by the glass. There are a small number of more economic wines but it works out better to hit the cocktails! I can highly recommend the old fashion with rye! Also, a point worth a mention, we checked out they sell their steaks before we went but for those that haven't or don't regularly eat in this type of restaurant you order by weight and the steaks are priced by the 100g so with the larger or sharing ones sold by how availability of each cut by weight so you don't know how much it will necessarily cost unless you do your mental arithmetic first. Not a crazy problem but just worth noting if you don't have unlimited funds!Overall our experience was pleasant and the food good but I won't be rushing back!

7tYtQGNVEIXwA-UwTO2sNA.text: Had a wonderful lunch here today. Everything was good but the noticeable difference was the service. I'm traveling in London (by myself) on business and recently had rotator cuff surgery so one arm is still in a sling, making things a little difficult...Not one but 3 different people offered to help me by cutting my steak or helping me prepare my food so I could get too it... Felt like I was 3 years old again but the hospitality was really appreciated. For the food, everything was great and the sticky toffee pudding was off the chart..!!

SumKP1p1HguNJYPxdXX5Og.text: Such a good taste for Music...that if added to a great and warm tea or coffee it'd be a real plus...

Q2la3znawg5k279uyjxbUw.text: There's no denying this is a great place to hang out in London. The bar downstairs usually has space even if you can't get a table upstairs. Probably not so great for vegetarians but if you get chips, make sure you ask for the blue cheese hollandaise sauce! And of course you can't go wrong with the cocktails. Piggy Stardust is a favourite but the bartenders are some of London's best for whatever takes your fancy.

_G8zoYLP_k0_2_Ai-dr0VQ.text: I stepped into an elevator with coworkers, minding my own business and on my way home, the next thing I knew I was at the Hawksmoor (Spitalfields) having a Christmas Burger in the downstairs bar. It's a limited time item and quite the experience! So glad I acquiesced.The burger is buttermilk fried turkey, a sausage patty, smoked bacon, sprout tops, spiced cranberry ketchup, and a slice of Ogleshield cheese. The taste you really get out of it is a bit of the sausage, some turkey and cheese, and the cranberry ketchup. Dipping it in the side of turkey gravy just makes that much better.As for puddings, the Salted Caramel Rolos and Peanut Butter Shortbread were definitely worth the guilt. Don't pass them up! So good!

dX3KTJCs49bgOTuElDpWfA.text: This Hawksmoor location just started serving Sunday Roasts and wow are they good!! I'd had the roast at the Seven Dials restaurant and it was tasty, but Spitalfields blew it away. The Yorkshire Pudding was enormous and so fluffy, the meat was perfectly cooked and tender, the roast garlic was delicious... everything was so well executed. The service was fabulous and the decor is very nice. I will be back for more meat!!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Sunday Roast!

BWiLxt2r54ki9QrdBbM6Nw.text: When my friend was visiting from the states and wanted to meet for lunch on Sunday, my first thought was a Sunday Roast. I make a pretty mean roast myself so it's hard for me to want to go out and get it. But where have I had the best Sunday Roast in London? Hawksmoor. Given he's a huge fan of musicals, I decided to not go to the Hawksmoor that I usually go to (Air Street) and instead try out the one in Spitalfields so he can see a different area of London.Unfortunately, we were a bit late in meeting him, but he managed to find it, and they had already seated him. We sat talking for a bit, and finally decided on some delicious Portuguese wine and a round of roasts for the three of us. (HIs was more well done, ours was pink).The roast was delicious as always. Moist and succulent meat with a whole head of roasted garlic and some roasted shallot. Amazing Yorkies and potatoes with some greens and carrots. Add in a delicious horseradish sauce and some bone marrow gravy, and life is golden. My partner and I also opted for the side of roast bone marrow because bone marrow.We also got a few sides including the triple cooked chips (the ones I make at home are better) and the mushrooms (yum). We also had dessert. I got the Crunchy bar which was amazing. Mostly decadent chocolate with a bit of salted caramel and honeycomb. My partner got the rolos because they are also amazing. My friend got the sticky toffee pudding. After trying to explain to him for a couple of minutes what clotted cream was like, we finally settled on telling him it's got the consistency of softened butter but is slightly sweeter. But he definitely enjoyed it, even though it did end up becoming sticky toffee pudding soup (he wanted it all mixed well).However, the service at this one is definitely more laid back and casual, and it was kind of annoying. We were often left alone, and having to ask for more water when we could. I think Air Street is still my preference, but it's always nice to get a bit of a change.

5GSCcKPLFApjKzd1HCzJ_A.text: On Sundays, we roast. And there's really no better place in London than Hawksmoor for Sunday Roast. The meat, the gravy, the potatoes roasted in duck fat, the great yorkshire pudding, the vegetables...so delicious. The gorgeous sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream deserves its own separate mention. It's probably enough to take 5 years off your life but oh, what a way to go!

ZrPq9LRWd3f4nJNOCWv_Sw.text: Everyone knows that I'm a fan of Hawksmoor.  I had only been to the one at Seven Dials (and also the one near Bank for desserts only), but this time, I decided to try out the one at Spitalfields.  And it did not disappoint.Generally, everything that I have said about Hawksmoor Seven Dials also applies to Hawksmoor Spitalfields.  The meat was done perfectly, and the sides were just as much of a treat as the steaks.  The service was solid, and the ambience stayed true to the hallmark Hawksmoor style.Having said that, two things that jumped out as different about Hawksmoor Spitalfields: 1) The menu seemed slightly limited compared to the other chains. For example, under sides, they didn't have asparagus, which Hawksmoor Seven Dials has.  2) The restaurant was less spacious but on the flip side, it was more cozy and hipster.  Probably the better choice if you're looking for a more intimate meal.My love for Hawksmoor continues!

YvaLtKzXLVCwD5Z1LhLZ6Q.text: Had a taste for a big league steak after a long day of running around and hopping on and off of the Tube, Overground, and DLR.

zyLBoCb3PZtEfbqd-afU7Q.text: I ate the ribeye and the fillet from Hawksmoor the other day, and it was the best steak I've ever had, and I'm not exaggerating. I preferred the ribeye because its skin was flavorful and crispy, while it was juicy and tender inside. It wasn't too fatty either. The desserts are also not to be ignored. I had English Strawberry Meringue and Peanut Butter Shortbread with Salted Caramel Ice Cream. Both tasted sweet and delicious yet distinct, and are definitely hard to find anywhere else. Our waitress, whose name I don't remember, was extremely kind and patient with us and even served us complimentary Sticky Toffee Pudding because we were enjoying the food so much! The food was quite pricey, but in return you get a great experience!

ciye1PTzE4HbmV8WNhhVbQ.text: The best steak you will have in your life! It. Was. So. Good. The side dishes were nothing to dismiss either, the Mac and cheese especially! And has some great wines. Only down side is very expensive, but to be expected of such a high quality place.

mHsK0kETCf_wx9NDK7GL9w.text: Holy Sunday roast, Hawksmoor!With Mum in town I wanted her to experience one of my favourite Britishisms: a proper Sunday lunch. I called all around: the Holly Bush, the Dock Kitchen, the Garrison, the Wells and all were fully booked or only had reservations after 3:00. I wanted to kick myself for not doing better pre-planning!And then I came upon it in an article in the Guardian. Best UK Sunday Lunch 2010: Hawksmoor, London. I rang them up and viola! A table for two at 12:30 secured!At first blush I liked the place with its warm, rustic feel and a friendly staff, some of whom, like us, were still waking up. Mum let me do the ordering and I called for one roast rump with all the trimmings (I mean, what's Sunday lunch without a Yorkshire pud?) I also got us the short rib bubble and squeak and the creamed spinach. In a dish certainly more appropriate for two came slabs of roast beef, a Yorkshire pudding bigger than most people's faces, carrots, potatoes and some greens. Add horseradish and you have a flawless meal! Never before have I been more pleased with a Sunday roast.The creamed spinach and bubble and squeak were also nice but next time I'll concentrate on the beef and all its trimmings (and there's always dessert...)To cap off our pre-Christmas celebration we shared a sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream. It was as decadent as you might imagine. I'm already planning my next Sunday excursion to Hawksmoor. Who's coming with?!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Sunday roast

mIAWyoqKAxXL_l-WXW7H9w.text: Hawksmoor is a classic, lively steakhouse with convenient locations throughout London. We visited the Spitalfields branch during our August trip and it has a quiet kind of swagger.The cocktail list is super in-depth, with lots of commentary. I had some kind of gin drink and my boyfriend a whiskey drink; both were good, though at a high cost.To start, we had bone marrow with caramelized onions (8 pounds), which was a great pairing and a huge portion for the price. Definitely get this if you're a bone marrow fan.We split a nice-sized chateaubriand (13 pounds per 100g, portions starting around 300g) with peppercorn sauce on the side. So good... perfectly cooked to medium rare. Great juicy texture and meaty flavor, with a mild sear. The side of mushrooms was probably good for our health, but skippable.Overall, this is reliable luxury food at reasonable prices. Service was fine; there were many bathrooms. It wasn't overly busy on a Monday but I would recommend booking ahead for the weekend.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Cocktail
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Cocktail
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow

816n-HeuksuaJA6P5b882g.text: Perfect steak dinner in London. We started with the bone marrow for appetizer. Very rich and fatty. Yum! We ordered the rib eye and strip steak with mac & cheese and creamed of spinach for sides. Steak were cooked to perfection. We ended the evening with the sticky toffee pudding topped with clotted cream - amazing! Service was wonderful and attentive. This is a must when in London!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom

YyW1VOPeC5NB3sNEHDbLEw.text: What I enjoyed most about this place as much as the food was the atmosphere. It's quite casual for a quality steak house and there was a lively vibe that made you feel welcomed.But let's not kid ourselves, the food is excellent! Juicy, perfectly cooked porterhouse steak for two and all the sides were amazing. Super cheesy mac and cheese went well with the decadent bone marrow. The chips were on par as was the well seasoned Caesar salad. The sauces were equally delicious: Stilton hollandaise and peppercorn gravy. Service was on point, orders taken on time and brought out quickly. The drink menu suits the establishment. They really know their meats here but also offer a nice selection of seafood including lobster. (Next time!) The dessert menu nearly tempted us but after a big, delicious meal we couldn't have fit another bite!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Porterhouse steak, mac and cheese with Caesar salad
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow, Caesar salad and Porterhouse

0HfTTu9KAkg8hoy0JTC0lg.text: My wife and I had a wonderful relaxed meal at Hawksmoor Spitalfields. I reserved here because I wanted to try Yorkshire pudding for the first time in my life. I was expecting some sort of heavy doughy dumpling kind of thing but it turned out to be light and flaky! Add unique potted meat under an airtight butter seal and delicious gravy and Yorkshire pudding turned out to be truly delicious!However, while the food was excellent, the service was truly the difference maker.We arrived early and sat at the bar on the main floor for a while. Johnny the bearded bartender from Spain, provided excellent service and drinks. He was friendly and enthusiastic and his delicious libations truly got us going in the right direction for a wonderful evening. The drink with strawberry infused gin was definitely outstanding. My wife actually enjoyed a gin-based drink and she's never been a fan of the gin until now, perhaps only at Hawksmoor in London!For history buffs who have perhaps read this far, I decided to learn more about the origin of the Hawksmoor name. As you might expect in London, a rich history awaited discovery!In 1711, parliament passed a law to build fifty new churches in London and Westminister. I believe the idea was to encourage the population to get more involved with organized religion. While only twelve churches were ultimately built, Hawksmoor designed six of them and contributed to the design of two others! The six churches designed by Hawksmoor were St Alfege's, St George's, Christ Church, St George in the East, St Mary Woolnoth and St Anne's Limehouse. Perhaps we'll visit them all on our next trip!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Steak!!!
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Yorkshire puddings, bone marrow gravy, and potted meat!!!
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Shaky Pete's Ginger Beer made with London Pride

2jWWUXeEZoNFOfkKBZyu8A.text: Steaks are brilliant here. However, their triple cooked chips are not up to good quality.... and bone marrow were a little too hyped up and tasted like old fat... ;___;I don't think I understand bone marrow to be honest with you... and I blame Anthony Bourdain for making this hip! Ha... Starter with the yorkshire was amazing... don't really care for the pate either way but the gravy was amazing with the Yorkies...Over all it alright. My friend loves it thou so I'm happy. :)

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Starter - potted beef and Yorkshire
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. 300g - good steak
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Bone marrow - side

I5FlBrrKWvCORn_KIELiNw.text: Hawksmoor cooked up one of the tastiest meals I've ever experienced. Our waitress (Kirin?) graciously guided us through the ordering process. Everything was masterfully cooked. The fillet's were brought to the perfect temperature and sliced just right. The Peppercorn and hollandaise sauces for the steak and broccoli were magical. The mash potatoes were rich and filled with flavor. As an American, I instantly tasted the difference in quality of meat compared to what is grown and raised in the states. My eyes are now opened to the full flavor of hormone-free grass-fed steak. Hopefully the U.S / U.K trade talks won't force Britain down the path of cheap tasteless beef. Thank you Hawksmoor Spitalfields for the great meal!

wl9mMp-LWt2ydY9rYYdNxg.text: Canefor the famous Sunday Roast and wasn't disappointed. We ended up splitting the meal as we weren't overly hungry. Everything was excellent! Ended the meal with their sticky toffee pudding with clotted cream--probably one of the best desserts I've ever had.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Amazing Sticky Toffee Pudding with Clotted Cream!
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Sunday Roast

xM_Xc_9RQ1yXsxH8dM7RGQ.text: Good drinks and great meat. My husband and I got reservations ahead of time but probably didn't need them for 5PM on a Friday. I had the French house drink which was deliciously fruity. We share the scallops to start which were like butter and melted in your mouth. The bone in prime rib 600g was a healthy portion and the béarnaise was a great touch.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. French house
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. 600g bone in prime rib

2vkIdAMxFHSBMYoUfBqHMQ.text: Wonderfully seasoned filet: salty and delicious!  The restaurant furniture, however, didn't live up to my expectations of a nice steakhouse.  When I'm paying a lot for a nice steak, I'd prefer more comfortable seating than the wooden benches we were sitting on.

isD5hW6yWgUIB9oBrp9IMQ.text: I don't leave many reviews but this place is awesome! Great service, great selection of drinks and very helpful bar staff... oh yeah and the steak was amazing!

mvSOhwYcVA8b1eFdtc1sfA.text: Going to London was a dream trip for me, and this restaurant was the cherry on top.The steal was incredible, the cocktails were delicious, and the Yorkshire pudding... well, I get it now!Amazing food, great service, incredible experience

rSijB-mreXKrFl9dwoLyvQ.text: So, so good. I went for the Sunday roast and it is pretty unbeatable. Great drinks selection. Awesome staff. It IS quite pricey but worth it for a special occasion! Enjoy.

KxTaAPUCA_b9_7A9_XiPDw.text: I cannot stop thinking  about the meal i had here. It was AMAZING. The porterhouse and rib eye were cooked to perfection with the best flavors I've ever had on a steak. The beef and bacon Yorkshire's were to die for. But the best part was dessert, my husband and i almost died when we ate the warmed chocolate tart with brown butter ice cream. He's very picky when it comes to any dessert, he said It was the BEST dessert he ever had. And i agree. The service was fantastic and i really hope we go here again before we leave!

tKlC_yIHYxjuSeTIR8RK7A.text: Ordred the baked scallops, Norwiegen Salmon for starters - I cannot reccomend the scallops any more highly, they were simply delicious and beautifully served. The salmon was also very good and of high quality, but for someone who eats this quite often, nothing to really write about other than what I already have about it.For the main course I ordered 700g Chateaubriand and a few sides which consisted of pureed potatoes, a romaine salad and creamed spinich all of which were delcious. To drink we had a bottle of Pinot Noir from my home state of Oregon. The wine was light and delicious, perfecgt with the steak we had. In total we sent around 400 quid. Worth it and will be back.

NQEX4EfFfaUg4yjfQMBDrQ.text: One of the best ribeye steaks I have ever had.  Noisy fun restaurant with good wine selection and casual ambience.  The Chateuabriand looked amazing as well and the chicken and sole dishes were tasty.  Get the horseradish and beet salad!  Excellent all around.  Will come again!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Wonderful porter.  Don't miss out!
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom

Lsc85eH9ZXIXH6iRugIjFQ.text: The atmosphere of this place is lovely, the service, great. What I really didn't enjoy was the steak! My partner had fillet and I the ribeye. Both were flavourful on the outside (nice and charred) but both steaks were TOUGH and mine super gristly and fatty. I had half of the 400g still in the plate at the end, just a pile of fat. And my partner's - good fillet should melt in the mouth and be super soft, but it was chewy and flavourless on the inside.This place is VERY expensive and I would expect the steak to be top notch - but it wasn't for me.  Sides are delish and wine list extensive, but I won't go back, as there are too many better places than this. Went on a Friday night and yes it was very busy, but the service was terribly slow. We waited far too long for our mains, like 40 plus minutes. When you go to a high end place, it shouldn't matter how busy it is - you should expect the same level of service as if it were a Wednesday. I'd say try a place where you get better value for money. I really don't see how they warrant the price for the quality that you get - won't be going back unfortunately.

69REflAIF8o4sc812AZZ-A.text: I'm quite the steak (and meat) lover so was looking forward to this resto recommended by several friends.    Upon reviewing the menu, we noticed the prices were quite fair but had expected gastronomical costs from the reviews.  (A quality steakhouse comes with a hefty price tag, no?)   We were impressed with some dishes and others, not so much.  1) Baked Scallops - BEST dish of the night.   It's an elevated version of an American baked clam.  2) Rib Eye with a side of bone barrow.  The incredible Bone Barrow was more than generously served (3 v large pieces for only 5.00!!) but the steak... oh the steak stopped me in my tracks, and not for the desired reasons.  The steak was heavily salted and tasted good, but not great.   I've had much better.  For a nearly damn perfect steak, try Mastro's if you're ever in the States.  A bit disappointed since this is a steak house.3) Macaroni & Cheese - the cheese was too sour for us.  We took one bite and couldn't touch it again.4) Caesar Salad - delicious5) Atmosphere - LOVE the feel.  Service was great (though they were a bit slow on the water uptake), from the bartenders to the hostess to the waitstaff.   I quite enjoy the more "hipster" feel as opposed to a stuffy, leather outfitted restaurant that makes a steakhouse feel expired.6) Cocktails - this was the best part of our night.  Loved the Free Unicorn that consists of Vodka, Cassis, Ginger, Passionfruit, Citrus & Soda.   So we may not be rushing to come back for a steak but definitely the bar downstairs, separate from the dining room, is worth a return. (4 stars for the bar, service & atmosphere.  3 stars if it were the steak only)

oSQ-yw6NNm8KrFZTE8oeAQ.text: Best Sunday roast in London. Came here on a Sunday afternoon at 3pm and the entire restaurant was full. I looked around and everyone is literally here for Sunday roast since they only offer it on the weekends. The triple fried chips (fries) with duck fat was great as well. I highly recommend it.

DmtlEw7xoLo16FcCUREI7g.text: This restaurant serves the best steak I have ever tasted! Yes it's not cheap but boy is it worth it! I am already counting the pennies so I can return again and sample the exact same meal. I opted for the sirloin medium rare with a side of sweet potato. Decent portion size and the texture and level of cooking couldn't have been better. To accompany I ordered a bottle of the Chateau Fontareche-exquisite! So much so we ordered another bottle to have downstairs in the bar. Already top of the list of places to go for a celebration! Highly recommend it to anyone.

T7shK1NGO2g459UmGh_D4A.text: Great for the lone business travel in search of a modernly rustic restaurant to enjoy great courses and good wine. I had a craving for steak after a multi-day workshop session for work. I mainly wanted a great piece of meat, some amazing wine, and an environment where I could melt away a bit and decompress. Fortunately I was seated in a corner table where I could have fun people watching while being able to sip away on my glass of wine.I will certainly recommend the garlic scallops, filet (with Stilton spread... when in England, right?), and sticky toffee pudding for dessert. Wine list had some good choices by the glass, but certainly better off to bring some friends so you can sample from their larger selection.If I find myself back in the area, I'd certainly plan to come back!

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Very tasty garlic scallops!

mDMKvwx_qBN30e1FJ7CQoQ.text: I LOVE YOU HAWKSMOOR! As good as it gets.  The Best Roast Dinner I have ever had (sorry mum!),  Perfectly roasted beef, a great Yorkshire Pudding and the potatoes well I have never tasted better! The staff were extremelly accommodating, polite and nothing was too much trouble from letting us order (keen diners) at 11:30am ready for service at 12noon to bringing us bread to soak up the Julep cocktails we were slurping before lunch!  OBTW, Julep cocktails are now my favourite thing!  There is nothing I disliked about this venue, it's food nor it's staff.  Absolutely wonderful!

gqglgxeRGmpaaP1iFa2CuA.text: What a decadent, and marvellous way to start the week - a Monday visit to Hawksmoor, a gin-rich aperitif, some red wine, about 400g of protein and fat, an Apple Brandy as digestif, and two quick Lagavulins as nightcaps in the Commercial Tavern opposite the road ... there's nothing like looking forward to the weekend on a ... Tuesday.Meat lovers, go. Chances are you are a bloke - the waitress told us that Valentine's Day was such a nice change, with its equal guy/gal ratio, because usually it's 90% guys ... which we could ascertain after a quick glance around the (almost full) dining room.Exposed brickwork, lots of cocktail shaking behind the bar, and the ultimate carnivorous gadget - a blackboard which simply lists the pieces of meat awaiting eager diners in the kitchen ... just a list of "800g, 800g, 850g, ..." and so on up to a terrific 1.5kg. That's a lot of red meat. Whenever a piece is ordered, the waiter or waitress will go to the blackboard and cross off your order.The menu encourages sharing (yes, dear reader, we know you're a really exceptionally hungry specimen, incredibly so, but just hold it right there - 800g is too much, even for you, showoff). It's a form of British tapas, if you like - sharing a cow.How was the meat? The meat was terrific (we had prime rib something). How was the red wine? Fairly pricey wine list; we were in the lower third of the menu with a 37.50 bottle ... but it was a fine tipple. Some triple-cooked chips, for atmosphere.Service was attentive and cheery. One dinner companion couldn't make up his mind on the aperitif, and so he just asked the waitress to ask the bartender to choose a drink for him - anything. Turned out as a nice whisky sour. So you see, the whisky theme was consistent.Well well - feeling slightly off-peakish today, but it was worth it. Go to Hawksmoor - especially if you're a girl. You can make a visible impact.

dT2wMCTWJy8EyRqgvnT1jg.text: We take the tube to Old street station and walked about 25 minutes to get there. The restaurant is busy. we tried the 650g steak for share in medium cook and the half lobster for starter. then creamed spinach and triple fried chips. the steak was good, but not good enough the impress me as i have already tried so many steak restaurant and I am sure this is not the best one :( Anyway, they got many choices on dessert and drinks. I would like to come again to try others maybe the gurger. We spend 140GBP for two ppl for the dinner not including any wines.

X7I6m12_FEEqcxe2nobkSA.text: this place is great!fantastic cocktails, made immediate friends with great bartenders.dinner was so much fun: great steaks (ribeye & filet), lobster, some sort of potato called 'jersey royals'. desert, fernet, cognac the great staff made the evening one to remember.we recommend it highly for both the food & the people!

u8cF5kAdralWx66XlW0yMw.text: Wow. Just... wow. I'm a little bit in love with The Hawksmoor now. And damn them, after serving me the yummiest steak ever, nowhere in London is really going to stand up. This really is the best steak I've ever had in London. One of the best ever. I like it here. It's utterly understated, but the staff are great. Fab barmen, who don't look at me weirdly when I explain my stupid berry allergy (but did politely check that they weren't going to accidentally kill me, which was nice). The winter punch for two was fab, all full of rhubarb gin and yum. But drinking from the same glass is fine at the bar, not so much over dinner. But they're forgiven. Because we supped up quickly, and got to ordering. Three rib-eyes, a medly of sides later and we were very happy campers. I was so happy with my steak. But I'll be honest, I'm teetering between four and five stars. Because my steak wasn't medium rare. It was more rare. My friend's was more medium than the medium rare he'd also requested. We were happy, but it wasn't what we asked for. This is just a little niggle, but if I'm paying £25 for a steak, I want it cooked as I asked. But, everything else was amazing. Eye watering horseradish. I'm not a huge fan of ketchup so wasn't bothered by it. But I think ketchup should taste of ketchup, rather than a bloody Mary. Heinz would do just fine. We had no room for dessert, which says just how enormous our steaks were. But I did polish of another glass of Rioja whilst my friends drank their coffee. That was very tasty. Steak and sides for three, with wine and cocktails was £166 with service. A little more than I was planning on spending (and not something I'm going to do every week), but it was so worth the trip. Even the little niggles don't stop me from giving this place five stars. We had a wonderful evening and I left with a bit of a steak high. Yay.

c2u2oJ5O72YyUrJ3HwhASg.text: Hawksmoor's breakfast is a relatively new offering and naturally it's geared towards the carnivore. We were offered so much awesome protein that it made us a little bit giddy, frankly. A deliciously acidic martini helped cut through a morning-after hangover and though a bottomless Bloody Mary is about the worst thing I could think of (loathe tomato juice), all the other diners raved about it. Full menu is available as well during breakfast serving hours which means the burger, only previously offered Mon-Fri, can be savoured at the weekend too. We'll be going back for that. Make sure you do ask if there is something you fancy that's off the menu as they're really accommodating. Reading other reviews here about the prices, I remembered that we got a discount (on the food) as it was the first weekend but the prices were comparable to say Roast's 2-for-1 breakfasts before 9:00 on Saturdays, but the food was better. Blogged here: bit.ly/d4po5d

pP4c_R1yxDjPY2H3Hpf1eQ.text: Steaks can't get better than this. Reserve early hours so you can order the limited Chateaubriand cuts that are to die for.

54pO3_9qOILvnBHlZ41Vcg.text: I have some catching up to do. For ten years, I was vegetarian so would never even consider a steak house. Now, steak houses aren't just a treat, they're catching up on lost time. And, while my level of comparison is possibly limited, the steak itself is going to have to go a long way to beat the one served at Hawksmoor. Cooked medium-rare it was tender and full of flavour. Make no mistake, this is good quality steak. You can't question this at all. Delicious, if a little strange that my friend's medium-rare steak was a little more bloody. Still, bloody delicious though, and all washed down by a delicious rioja But I've hovered between giving this three and four for a few different small niggling reasons. Firstly, it is a lot to spend on a meal (a bill for three came to over £160 - EDIT: I accidentally said it came to £200. My memory must have been hazy because of the wine). Second, it's a very nice restaurant but it doesn't quite feel like the special event that a £200 for 3 meal you'd expect. And then there's the difference in cooking between two medium-rare steaks. Forgivable in a standard restaurant, but one that's surprising from a steak specialist. But, dammit, it's hard to give this three stars when the steak is just so delicious and the wine so nice. If it turns out I can get just as tasty steak for less elsewhere, I reserve my right to amend this review. Somehow, I'm not sure that I will.

d70YK12bq4pULOqxcFbVEQ.text: I walked straight past when heading to meet my fellow steak lover. Hawksmoor has that Shoreditch vibe about it, extending as far as having no signage whatsoever on the street that I could see. The interior is dark and trendy, and a perfectly comfortable place to spend a couple of hours, but not quite as up market as you might associate with some of the prices on the menu. Once inside we got down to business. Passing on starters, we went straight into finding out if this really is one of the best places in the city to fulfill an urge for steak. I ordered the fillet steak, rare, and triple cooked chips. London is always a difficult place to know how to order steak, in some places a rare steak will come just about warm down the middle, whilst in others (Gaucho for example) it will come close to blue, with a sliver of cold meat down the middle. Hawksmoor is the latter, as my steak appeared to merely have been told where the grill was, but not really introduced. The steak arrived sat alone in the middle of the plate fat and plump - the menu said 300g but I definitely got lucky here as it appeared far bigger - with the chips served in a china cup to the side. The flavour of the steak was fantastic, left with little more than salt and pepper to get in the way of the chargrilled beefy goodness. However the big niggle I found was just how much a sauce on the side was missed. As much as I like the simple idea of letting the taste speak for itself, it could really have benefited from a nice peppercorn sauce mixing with the blood and juices seeping out that you can dip your chips in. Even one served in a pot on the side if they don't want to ruin the aesthetic of the steak taking pride of place on an empty plate. The chips were also a bit disappointing for their price (£4.00), they were certainly good, but no better than any decent gastropub can muster these days. For dessert a Sticky Toffee Pudding kept my fellow diner happy, and my citrus sorbet with gin was a delicious and refreshing palate cleanser after the meal. Two steaks, two chips, two puddings and a couple of bottles of sparkling water came to around £90. Very good, would definitely consider it as an alternative to Gaucho next time I'm in the mood for a pricey steak, but the sides could do with some attention.

eMFtz12ZGatKyrsNbql2Pw.text: Oh Hawksmoor, you were supposed  to be 5 stars.  But here's what happened.  Loved the casual vibe, the great atmosphere, the lovely yet pricey wine, and our oysters.  The steak portion was huge, and I didn't feel that it came medium rare--it was full-on rare.  And the chips were good, but they weren't blow my mind.  The service was really good, but the food came out slow.  And it was pricey--25-30 quid for the steak alone....it all added up to quite a pricey but slightly underwhelming affair.

lUu6JxVpmvbnh4mMqMczAQ.text: Given that the meat for this restaurant comes from the Ginger Pig and that Jay Rayner of the Observer describes it as: The best steak I have ever eaten in this country you might expect better, but when I went last time, about a year ago, the rump was as tough as a leather boot and enough to make my jaw ache for hours afterward. I won't be heading back any time soon, though my brother swears by the place and frequently visits. I suppose it is a case of one bad experience souring my palette, and of course no two cuts are the same, but you can only learn from your experience right?

sOrAuf1CbPspmEtkbVdFNw.text: Simply superb.  Had a steak with bone marrow.  Cooked perfectly and delicious.  Importantly,the marrow bones were properly cut longitudinally rather than transversely.  Great wait staff, who were friendly  very  familiar with the menu.   Highly recommended.

jwyMiYTdAAUaSaGxDEkROw.text: If you want a fine steak in Central London, then the word on the street is that this is one of the places to try out. And it certainly should be on the list, although perhaps not the sole entrant. If you can summarise Gaucho as good steaks served in uber-glam locations, then the Hawksmoor could also be characterised as good steaks and cocktails served in a humble, almost quiet location. You can almost see Brown/Blair having made their deals here, if this was in Islington. The restaurant was surprisingly busy for a Monday night, which meant service was a little wanting, but that's understandable. Not everyone can get served like that, but it does get annoying. The main problem is the price. The most cost-efficient big steak is 600g of bone-in sirloin - which comes in at £26. It's fantastically gorgeous meat cooked just right, but you're definitely paying for it. The steak I chose was succulent, delicious, and just the right side of raw. Likewise, the starter of Tamworth belly ribs was equally succulent, tender to the taste and delicious. With the exception of the macaroni'n'cheese, the fixings weren't quite as up to scratch, but eminently edible and good enough. Just not great. I wish I could report on the puddings, but I don't remember a thing about the puddings. I think salt/seasoning and alcohol overload had hit by that point. The cocktail menu was wide and varied, and I wish I'd had more time to sample some of them. All in all, a place to prepare for - don't drop in on a whim. Research your meats and cocktails, starve yourself - it's a marathon, not a sprint. And it's gorgeous delicious food. But if you want to impress a date, perhaps Gaucho's would be a better 'experience'.

TzitfIByXPikqD1Sa0JkZw.text: It's finally happened. I finally made it to Hawksmoor. To eat their legendary meat. I'm not joking when I say I've been waiting to go here since they opened. Which was years ago. I could never persuade my friends to go, due to spendiness, nor my family since it doesn't seem posh enough for a proper blow-out. Anyway, to introduce this, my expectations were sky high. So was it the transcendental steak experience I was expecting? Yes, and as usual, no. To cut to the chase, the meat is flawless. Faultless. Best of breed. The sides are also perfect in their own little way. Best macaroni cheese I've had in London. Great chips. Good crisp to fluff ratio. Nice wine. Pricy cocktails. The big, big problem with Hawksmoor is it costs about 25% more than I think it should. You're looking at £70-80 for three courses plus booze, and it's just not special enough for that kind of money. The things that keep it out of that bracket are the state of the dining room, the staff, the speed of service and the weird City / Shoreditch location. I think these guys could have nailed Gaucho to the wall, but it's just too expensive for me and mine, despite being the committed carnivores we are. Go. If someone else is picking up the tab.

FrOPaPtD_GC3nrGgX4P2aA.text: Hawksmoor Restaurant In a subtly lit room towards the back of the venue, the table was laid for 12 Qype people. With cocktails and wine on offer from the outset, the red velvet wallpaper was soon a distant memory. The restaurant was apparently short-staffed and running completely full, an unusual occurrence which was what accounted for the significant delays. The cocktails are not what made this place such a draw on a Monday evening and that draw is related to the images drawn in pencil on paper on the walls to the ladies  it was the MEAT. Yes, it was another Qype meat-up and this time it was at the wonderful Hawksmoor restaurant which serves what has to be the finest selection of MEAT I have seen for awhile. Trusting in the chef, I ordered a prime rib steak thing of some sort of flamed level which was bliss. I'm not sure what I was eating there for awhile because I had entered a sort of meaty heaven. Each bite was a lovely melt-in-the-mouth sensation which required all your attention. My fellow Qypers were briefly forgotten in the silent bliss that followed our service. While the meat itself was great, special mention has to go to the dessert which I am not entirely sure how I managed to eat after the generous meat and healthy salmon starter. The hot fudge brownie ice cream thing with the extra hot chocolate sauce was worth the visit alone had I not eaten MEAT. Trust the chef and order a nice cut of meat. Let the chef cook it to the meat's best temperature and you will have a blissed-out evening but be warned  STARVE YOURSELF so that you can enjoy both a starter AND pudding or you'll regret it ;-)

dCbko2y7BtCRhySwZXgnYQ.text: The Hawksmoor is widely touted as the best place to have a steak. Naturally a venue which has garnered such praise from the meat-eating sphere is just asking for a visit from the dedicated Qype meat eaters, and so we duly set off there for a Qype Meat Up (qype.co.uk/groups/883-Qy…) . And oh my, it delivered on its promise. We took our time working up to the meat with an array of cocktails, punch and starters. The cocktail menu is exhaustive and individual - I ordered a couple of ones called Hawksmoor - both very well mixed, refreshing and generous with the old alcohol. While I didn't order my own starter I managed to badger one of the boys into 'donating' a bit of pork belly. Yes, good. Out of nowhere we were then produced with a bowl of Hawksmoor summer punch - a delicious fruity and awfully dangerous concoction - one of those that tasted just like the best juice ever while drugging you slowly. And so, before long an amazing 400g rib eye steak was produced before me (and a few others - though you'll have to read on below for details of what the non-ribeye lot chowed through). I'm a rib eye girl through and through and I've not tasted anything like this before - perfectly chargrilled meat with a beautiful vein of fat running through it. This thing of beauty set me back £22, and though this is over a week's food budget for me just now, oh my, it was worth it. We had a whole bunch of sides alongside the meat. My abiding memory is that they were not all that special, and though the mac n cheese is worth a mention. This may be tactical to keep the focus on the meat - it works. In the post-meat and red wine haze we ordered a variety of desserts - I have to say, again, nothing overly special. I'm not sure if this is because the memory of the steak was so close to us, or if we were a little worse for wear, but I have the feeling that they just weren't that special. Very lovely of course. Probably not worth the prices. However, as it's been pointed out below, there's next to no point mentioning the prices here. You don't come here for a cheap meal - you come here for a glorious feast. Go to the Hawksmoor and you make that choice! To accompany the meal we had a few (!) bottles of delicious Rioja between us (though I am the first to admit I know less than nothing about wine and had to be told how to check and taste it - someone else do this for me please) - and very good it was too. In summary then, it's all about the meat. I had such a fantastic time with a proper meal with all the trimmings and ceremony, hanging out with some awesome Qypers, however, will sit tight in the knowledge that I can return for just a rib eye and a glass of red wine and leave as one of the happiest girls alive. Everything else is just distraction.

5lP5OqwgZt6VMeiF-tB2JQ.text: I went to the Hawksmoor Bar on Monday as I was attending the Qype Meatup. I had heard lots of good things about the Hawksmoor and was really looking forward to eating there - after having been a vegan of sorts lately, I could hardly wait to have my steak. We were given a table in a semi-private room. Maybe this was done in consideration of the other guests; we had wine on the house and perhaps they were not sure how rowdy we would become during the course of the evening ;) The evening started off with our complementary cocktails. I ordered a whiskey sour, which was a tad too sweet and there wasn't much whiskey in it (which happend to be a good thing - I was starving and a strong drink on an empty stomach would have floored me). My starter was the pig belly ribs, which were nicely seasoned. I was then served the rib eye steak, medium rare, and was treated to a great piece of meat that was perfectly done. It is obvious that the meat is carefully sourced as the quality is faultless. The side dishes were fine except for the gem salad; the dressing was not my cup of tea at all but maybe it was just me. The potato gratin, on the other hand, was to die for. The chocolate fudge sunday was very good as well and contained good-quality ice cream but it was a bit too much after all the other food so I was unable to finish it (much to the delight of a fellow Qyper). We were served a great red, which was lovely and went very well with the food. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable and when the food was served the plates were allocated to the correct diners without the serving staff having to ask around, which is quite good given that we were a table of 9.I would come back again for the great steaks but the prices keep this place from being an everyday treat.

nvMO_EjBSoTA480wPn6hkQ.text: I had the ribeye with grilled bone marrow and had the mushrooms on the side. The combination of the beef and marrow was out of this world. I was very pleased with the way the steak was cooked, med-rare with a slight char on the outside, and the quality of beef compared to other places was apparent on the first bite. The place was good for groups (real friends not fake ones) and the service was great compared to most London service I've experienced. I will definitely hit this place up again and again.

PXVJkZDFxv3vHQgzMwbhHw.text: Mmmmmmm, meat, meat, meat, meat yummmmy Oh, sorry, I was just reminiscing about the sirloin steak I devoured at Hawksmoor Bar mmmmm, yuuummmm oh, sorry I got distracted again, hehehe :) Well, what could a carnivore like me do if presented with such a fine big steak but drooling and mumbling? I mean, come on, you can't blame me for that! Oh, what big sirloin steak they've got there at Hawksmoor Bar! It was literally the biggest steak I've ever had in one go, 600 gr yes! Wooohoooo! I actually didn't want to share it with my fellow Qyper who sat next to me but I had to be polite so I offered him some because I could sense that he was still hungry even after having his rib eye. Needless to say, he loved his part of my sirloin steak but had the courtesy to say no when I offered him some more. All my life, I consider myself as a true carnivore because I must always (and I mean always) have some sort of meat in my food, apart from sweet dessert i.e. cakes etc. So, when I heard that there is a meat feast for some lucky Qypers at Hawksmoor Bar, I desperately signed on and just prayed to God that I would be on the list so that I could have a piece of those delicious steaks. My prayer was answered by MissRachelle, hahaha! She put me on the list and I was definitely in for a real treat.. Yes, my steak was big and big and big and meaty and yummy. Before my big steak, I had fresh oyster which were delicious. I wish I had ordered the scallops too because they looked super fine. Then, right after my biggy sirloin steak, I felt like I was in heaven when I delighted my senses with the best chocolate fudge pudding I have ever tasted in my life! My goodness, it was. (I'm actually speechless here, guys) That was it, a wonderful night with the best ending concluded. Well, maybe the best ending would be if Richard Gere suddenly showed up out of nowhere and offered me to go to South of France with him, but hey, you cannot have everything that you want, right? Hehehe In short, if you think you love meat and a true carnivore, seek no more! There's Hawksmoor Bar for you out there. Yes, you might have to pay a bit more, but it will be worth it. Or if you are simply curious about the heavenly experience I was talking about (see above reference), then you definitely need to go to Hawksmoor Bar and order the Chocolate Fudge Pudding! Remember it by heart, or better yet, write it down so that you won't forget :) And as for the cocktail, well, I don't drink alcohol and I just had coke with ice but based on the looks on my fellow Qypers' faces, I could tell that they were really happy. Ecstatic, if I may say so, and I believed the cocktails (and the meat of course) had something to do with it. One of them even had some sort of an almost orgasmic look on his face, but I won't tell you who that was, hahaha! Anyway, once again, if you love your meat, then you need to check out Hawksmoor Bar. Trust me!

LTHIOdLZkhiJZ6tCbpKWtA.text: Meat. Meeeeeat. The Hawksmoor is an average-sized restaurant, subdued and classy. They have a unique and varied cocktail menu (they didn't all work brilliantly for me, but it was fun trying - though at £8 per cocktail you mightn't want to try too many). Great service, too, they really took care of us. Though I was part of a group here for a special Qype event. Yeah, yeah, yeah, whatever. You come to the Hawksmoor for meat. And it delivers that. Meat. Especially beef. There were chicken and pork and fish dishes, I think. There's a generically-labeled "vegetarian" dish for a tenner. There were starters, too, and I managed to slide some quite tasty oysters down my neck. But really, you come here for beef. There are four standard steaks you can get: a 300g fillet for £30, a 600g bone-in sirloin for £26.50, a 400g rib-eye for £22 or a 400g rump steak for £19.50. They also have various sizes (they'll have to tell you on the night) of prime rib, porterhouse (each at £6 per 100g) and chateaubriand (at £12 per 100g). And oh, sweet god, are they ever good. I shared a medium-rare sliced porterhouse with two other people. It was undoubtedly some of the best beef I've ever had: juicy, perfectly cooked, intensely flavoured, and softly textured. Charred on the outside, scarlet red in the middle, it looked as good as it tasted. Yes, it's on the pricey side. But it is soooo worth it for the occasional celebration of how a bit of roasted cowflesh can be a transcendental experience. Meeeat.

9q8bDUayY9VYV_reiVaHGA.text: May the second meeting of the UYE Steak Club come to order!We decided to order large pieces of meat and share them among ourselves, because this place is glorious and you can buy meat by the weight. One group got the chateaubrianed and the other got the Bone-In Prime Rib. The waitress recommended the amount we should order per person and offered to bring it to the table cut for us ready for sharing, great service!It can get a little hectic with a large group of friends (we were 8) and deciding your meat options here. But if you have a group of people who love meat and aren't picky and have an awesome waitress like we did, then you'll be fine. Highlights of the meal for me: Bone-In Prime Rib: the meat of course, duh. Even the fatty edges were amazing. not a piece was abandoned. Greasy high five to Eamon B for shamelessly gnawing the meat off the bone. That's how it's friggin done!Georgia Mint Julip: served in traditional metal cup and a shite ton of ice. delicious and smooth and just the thing I needed to contrast the heavy meaty awesomeness in front of me. Check out their list!Triple Cooked Chips: okay so you don't go to the steak house to order the sides but seriously get these people. The triple "cooking" makes a huge difference. salty and crispy but soft middle. yum to the tenth degree.Sticky Toffee Pudding: there are no words. just order it for yourself and see.Con: Im a mac and cheese lova. and it was not good here but like I said, You don't go to the steak house for the sides. Stick with the spinach and chips if you need a little something something wif your meat.

vlWDn5L8eORbadONRt-ZXw.text: Hmmmmmmmm. I found this in my guide book, it only suggested to have a drink there....so I did and it changed the way I will look at cocktails FOREVER.  Ended up having another, and then a bunch of "tastes" of things (huge long story that eventually ends at Gerry's Liquors, never mind- you had to be there.) Easily the best cocktails on the island or anywhere. Bartenders were super friendly and entertaining- who knew cocktail concocting was so deliriously entertaining. Yes, there were flames and juicings and spritses but why you are still reading this and not picking out your outfit to wear to go see for yourself, I'll never know. Apparently it's in the middle of a super popular steak joint....oops!

8hs9wM4OcxI08lclXGoLFg.text: Quite easily the best roast dinner I've ever had. And I've had a few.I'd been to the Seven Dials restaurant for a fantastic steak previously, so knew we were on to a winner from the beginning, but I didn't appreciate just how good it would be. And it was great value too.£17.50 for rump steak with all the trimmings. The meat had a beautiful charcoal taste and was pink and juicy. Not quite melt-in-your-mouth soft, like their other steaks, but very very good. The duck-fat roasties greeted with full-mouth murmurs of appreciation and the carrots considered to be 'fantastic' by someone who claimed to not actually like carrots.Started the day with a jug of Pimms to celebrate the long weekend and this was topped up by a really rather lovely, but yet their cheapest, Pinot Noir.A friend of ours bucked the trend and tackled the 650g ribeye steak by himself. I've never seen anyone quite so happy as he when it was put on the table. It was a beautiful piece of meat. Not cheap, mind.  What is good value is that you can get all the roast-dinner trimmings for £5 (roasties, Yorkshire pud, carrots, shallots, cabbage, gravy etc) so a smaller steak with the trimmings is actually a great option on a Sunday. (sides are about £4 each normally).Will be back for their Brunch next - the HKmuffin and the breakfast for two are particularly appealing!

g9cYdNjgIAm2QKG-j_4SUQ.text: Steak Club 2.0 brought 8 of us down to The Hawksmoor on a wednesday night last week, where we gnawed (litterally in the case of Eamon who picked up the bone from his bone in cut) on massive quantities of succulent MEAT. (yes that totally deserved all caps).Tisha and i shared the Bone Marrow starter, which was ok. needed more salt and the caramelized shallots were a little over powering. the MEAT itself was freaking amazing. hit all the right buttons in so many ways. the sides were alright.. the mac n cheese needed a little something but the chips were good. the bernaise sauce (which i generally consider to be a gift from the gods) was a let down. the taragon was a bit few and far between, for my liking. i normally am not a huge BBQ sauce fan, but whatever it was in the bottles that were on the table was freaking out of this world. smoked ketchup? something mouth watering, thats for sure. and then the desserts. we got the chocolate sunday, which was what it was: good. and then the sticky-toffy-pudding-omg (to be said in all on breath). hello, lover. i want to enjoy you everynight, waist line be damned. not too sweet, but just perfect.and the drinks!! yum. very drinkable. as in 'oh look its gone.' our service was good, but it felt like ou waitress was at the end of a very long day. i know we were a large-ish group, but we were very easy going. and i know upselling is the name of the game with waiting tables, but i felt like we were pushed into getting a bit more then we needed. example: i figured that 850 grams of Chateaubriand would have been enough to feed three people, who were also getting loads of sides, a starter and was planning on getting dessert. but she insisted that we would need more. granted we ate almost everything, but we didnt need to. then with the cooking temps, her attitude bugged me. i know that a rib eye is best served medium, but if yorue ok with having a little fat and tendons around medium rare is ok. and if she had just said something like that i would have been fine. but she very kurt response of 'no we dont do that,' just didnt do it for me. last word:MEAT  = amazing.drinks = awesomeside and service = hit and miss.i'll give it 4 stars, but im almost tempted to give it 3.

c37SXHmhWHU8ReMKSCKVfg.text: I've had a couple good meals at the Hawksmoor.    I thought the steaks were very good and cooked to my liking.It would me nice if they at least gave you a complimentary bread basket and butter.  Speaking of butter, last time they served me two small sweet potatoes, dry...no butter.The hostess/greeting was welcoming.  The service, however, is not very attentive or professional.  At the price, you expect a bit better service.

iRsfFav-wwEdJhmZEBQc_w.text: Hawksmoor is the best recommendation that i have got from Yelp till date. I love steak and am always on the look out for new good steak houses. After reading about it, I had to try this one since its so close to where i live and work ... and i completely agree with the great reviews this place has been getting.I went alone for my first visit. Besides the standard fare of rumps and fillets, Hawksmoor had special bone-in prime rib, porterhouse and chateaubriand that were priced per unit mass of the meat. I enquired about the size of the available portion and i was told that they started from 650 gm. Too much for one non-American man ... even if he is a glutton like me. I will have to come again with a bigger group, i thought, before i dug into the fillet.The next time when i came with 3 other voracious meat-eaters like me, we ordered a 850gm porterhouse (along with a fillet). The meat was lovely ... clearly the best steak i have ever had. The meat was soft, and perfectly cooked. The staff is very knowledgeable and gave us, on demand, a lot of information about each of the cuts and the best way to eat them (even the wall decorations had such trivia). We ordered a variety of side dishes and sauces. Again ... Hawksmoor makes the best chips i have ever had. Add on the bearnaise or the hollandaise sauce ... and you have every ingredient necessary for a perfect meal.Wait. Did i say every ingredient ? I must be mistaken ... for i haven't even mentioned the drinks yet. Like any good steak restaurant, it has a decent selection of accompanying wines. But it also excels in making great cocktails (at a not too outrageous price of ~£8 per drink). I tried the Hawksmoor fizz, which they claim is their tribute to the famous Ramos gin fizz. Frankly, i wouldn't be able to tell the difference. The drink i was most attracted to was the Zombie (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zo…) ... primarily because there was a restriction of atmost one per person. I took up the challenge. In terms of alcohol content, it surely was equivalent to at least 5-6 normal cocktails (the picture i am posting might reveal how big the drink really was). I spent the whole afternoon after drinking that sloshed, and with a splitting headache.The food is expensive ... a typical meal will set you back by about £50 per person. But even then, its extremely popular and its almost impossible to get an evening reservation at short notice. Its a great place to go to for a special occasion.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. The Zombie

oVGDKakJ-dboLJjupGX1sQ.text: Steak and Beer?  Yup.Steak and Red Wine?  Of Course.Steak and Cocktails???   Hmmmmm, in-ter-est-ing......This place is pretty much my idea of heaven - I had SUCH a good time when I went.We had the Chateaubriand steak (about 800g is a pretty fair sized portion for two people sharing), triple fried chips and the best Sourdough bread I've had in years.  We actually sent the Steak back at first as we'd asked for Medium Rare and it looked VERY rare - the waiter explained it looks a little underdone compared to normal steak places as their meat is hung for a lot longer.  Nevertheless, he took it away without making us feel stupid and brought it back about 1 min later - when I actually tasted the meat I was so grate full that he hadn't taken it away and fried the life out of it - mouth wateringly succulent and tasty as hell - truly fantastic.We had Corpse Reviver 2 Cocktails to go with the main course - perfect combination.  Would definitely recommend this place and come back.

4AT4c51GElPCgyjcASeAuA.text: Best steak I've ever had. Period.Of course, the price was the highest I've ever paid. I split a 1kg Chateubriand with a friend of mine. We were completely stuffed, but it tasted awesome.The red wine was good too.

_YHaoy8Xg5DZtCe9PPxT7Q.text: Fantastic food, fantastic cocktails and lovely, unpretentious staff. I wish I could afford to eat here more often but for special occasions we eat like kings! The surf n' turf (half a lobster and a fillet steak) is amazing.

nO2gld9MOtaOir6of7RVFw.text: The location of the best birthday dinner I've ever had, and trust me, that's saying something.I've been here before, and had some of the tastiest steak in existence. When my 25th came around, I realised that all I wanted to do was drink amazing red wine, eat good meat and be with my friends. So that's exactly what I did.I booked a table for 15 online about a month ago, and got a nice email confirmation in return. Though they asked me for card details to reserve the space (not unusual for such a large group), I didn't get an email in the week leading up to Friday. However, a phone without battery on my part and the opening of a new place for them (in Seven Dials, Covent Garden) resulted in a voicemail, another call and a chat with the truly lovely restaurant manager. She said that we could arrive from 6pm and have the table for the whole night.I was late (oops), but my friends were gathered at the bar happily sucking down on cocktails and gin served by the super-capable barmen. Then to the table, situated at the back, with curtains you can pull to separate yourself from the main restaurant if you so wish. A decent time spent looking at the menu resulted in us choosing various steaks. I went for the 400g fillet, whereas other friends shared the porterhouse and some went for sirloin. I think we tried pretty much every cut they had. Sides come as extra, and range from triple-cut chips to garlic mushrooms (almost, *almost* as good as the steak itself), sweet potato, spinach and greens plus more.We spent the evening eating (well, drooling over the amazing meat), chatting with our waiter and drinking fab Cotes du Rhone.It's not cheap here (£60 a head for one course, an insane amount of wine and paying for me between them), but god, the meat is just stunning. I'll keep going back and back and back. Our waiter was on top form - though did pour red wine over my shoes at one stage  but leapt for soda and then told me to send them the bill - and got a 10% tip for it.Wonderful evening, finished by my boy getting the entire place to sing happy birthday to me (first time ever and made me blush). Just *go*. You'll love it if you appreciate good steak and great service.

2EAIcZuU_JpF5wzx-UmOOw.text: Yet another review from the Qype Meat Up...! So let's start with the good points. As everyone else here has mentioned the steak is transcendentally good. I think my share of the Porterhouse was £19, and many of the other steaks seemed to be around the £20 price mark. Given that you'd pay £10-15 for a rubbish steak in a gastro-pub, the Hawksmoor steaks are brilliant value and perfection in a beef-based format. So what about everything else? Well, I wasn't impressed. The service was almost painfully slow, and it took well over an hour in between ordering our meal and receiving our main course. The banter was good enough that I didn't feel time passing too slowly, but we then waited another hour to get our desserts. It got to the point where a couple of people around the table were beginning to wonder whether they'd make the last train home! The starters, side dishes and puddings were pretty average, and probably a bit over-priced given how ordinary they were. The cocktail range was impressive, but the actual drinks were again quite ordinary, with the alcohol often overwhelming the other flavours. I've certainly had better cocktails, and for the price Hawksmoor are charging they should be of a higher standard. I also thought the wine list was fairly expensive, although as mentioned in other reviews, we weren't paying for drinks ourselves! I'm not sure if I'd go to Hawksmoor again, but if I did I'd get a massive steak and not much else.

photos.caption: Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. sweet sweet 900g porterhouse
Photo of Hawksmoor Spitalfields - London, United Kingdom. Crab without a decent amount of bread

ai6OeyBLbAQPNjOuv2i6ew.text: We went here to expand our range of Sunday roast places.  This place also looks like a steak restaurant and somewhere you can go for a huge fry-up.The server was friendly.  We were seated at a table for two in the main room and she noticed that it was a little wobbly.  So she helped to stabilise the table with a few bits of cardboard under a couple of the legs.  Apparently the floor is a bit old and not entirely flat.  I appreciated this level of attention; many places would just leave you to deal with it.I was a little confused by how the Sunday roast worked by looking at the blackboard.  But, it was explained how it told us the different cuts of meat available and the weights.  We both went for the rump roast with all the trimmings for 17.50 each.  It was a generous helping and we both left feeling full and satisfied.  (This is one of the most important criteria for a Sunday roast - I'm not planning on eating much else for the rest of the day.)The beef was nicely cooked - not too well done.  The highlight for me was the potatoes roasted in duck fat.  I like the crunchy outer layer and the fluffy inside went well with salt and gravy.  The yorkshire pudding is also a decent size, you can cut it up into sectors and mop up the surplus gravy.This was on the more expensive side of the Sunday roasts we have tried so far, but I would be happy to come back here.

23GvdnOWF3gPAEsODPbdyg.text: Came here for lunch yesterday. I had heard that the steaks were good, and it was not a let down. I started with the scallops, served on the shell, and they were beautifully presented and just delicious. I had the fillet with mashed potato and creamed spinach. The steak was juicy and tasty, the mash potato came in a little ramekin with gravy on top and was simply divine. The creamed spinach was as good as I have ever had. The wine list was excellent, and the only thing that let the meal down was the service. I'm being mean, probably, but the guy messed around with the glasses of water, even changing them to a smaller size when he hadn't been asked to do so. He served the ice separately, and generally fussed about. Weird. Having said that, it didn't detract from a fantastic repast which I really enjoyed and I'm going back for more.

F684celDeHf7yM3Ky-7wPw.text: To all those who think "this is the best steak ever. Period." are either first time steak eaters, or delusional. First off, Hawksmoor does not compare to NYC steakhouses--which are amazing ; and secondly, they certainly don't compare to the best steak house in London--which is JW at Grosvenor House. The prices are expensive, just like JW, but the quality, service and taste at Hawksmoor fall short of JW. Now it ain't all bad--the positives include great ambiance, great cocktail list and decent side dishes (although JW mash kicks Hawksmoor's mash to the curb). The cons? Well, for the same money you can go across town to JW and get better steaks, service and dessert. (Kind of a no brainier!) The worse thing I ate during my dining experience was the smoked salmon starter; it was very fishy, not sliced thin enough and the accompliments were anything but complimentary to the fish. The best thing I ate was the roasted mushroom side dish. My steak, the filet mignon, was good enough to finish--but nothing special; certainly nothing to warrant a return trip back. Bottom line: if you are looking for a real steakhouse and amazing steaks, go to JW and leave Hawksmoor to the amateurs!

-zgVJUaP5TrmaAjTBYYW0Q.text: Those bastards at Hawksmoor - they've ruined me.Could I be talking about my wallet? Perhaps - Hawksmoor is not cheap. In truth, their margins are actually reasonable, given that all of their meat is sourced from the Ginger Pig - some of the best meat you'll ever try, but you sure as hell pay for it.Do I mean my waistline? Once again, maybe - we invariably end up over-indulging here, and I think I do my daily allowance of calories in beef alone.But no, what I really mean is that Hawksmoor has utterly ruined my ability to simply enjoy a steak anywhere else. Every steak-eating experience is now simply an exercise in commenting on how "It's alright, but it's no Hawksmoor". This is coming from a guy who knows his beef inside out - if cows were humans then I should be in the Hague for genocide. Even when the BSE scare occurred, I simply declared "fantastic, all the more for me, and at better prices!" and proceeded to make as much of a dent in the European beef mountain as I could.OK, so we've established that, yes, the beef is amazing. The prices are high (but fair). The portions are vast, though you can eat somewhat lightly if you are careful.The ambience, especially since the redesign, is great - they've kept the exposed brickwork and dark wood environs, but there's a lot more space now, and a lick of paint has got it looking even fresher. Service is still top notch, be it Noél the bar manager who is a legend in his own time (always ready with a grin and some expertly devised cocktail), Tim the general manager who is always completely on top of everything and ensures the smooth running of the restaurant, or the handful of very competent wait-staff.The wine list is exceedingly well-priced with some absolute corkers on there - the wine buyers really know their stuff. Likewise, the cocktail list is a great collection of renditions of classics, plus some innovative (but not over-done) new creations courtesy of the expert bar team here.Special kudos needs to go to their sides too - sublime mac and cheese, some of the best fries in London and arguably one of the finest bearnaise sauces I've ever had the privilege of trying. If you've, miraculously, got any space left after the main course, desserts are equally delightful - the sundaes are a can't miss, but I'd advise sharing between 2 or 3 unless you have a super-human appetite.Of particular note is their (once monthly?) fixed price wine evenings they do, when the vineyard owners/wine producers pop over from various exotic locales to talk about the wines being served in vast quantities in conjunction with shedloads of beef and good lobster. All of this they usually do for £50-75 for effectively an all-you-can-eat/drink night, which given the usual prices and the sheer quantity available, is one of the best deals in London in my opinion.They've also just started doing weekend brunch and Sunday lunch. I haven't tried this yet, but will definitely be giving it a go within the next month or two. All in all it's an absolute must-try. I think I've taken 50+ people here over the years that it's been open, and I think only 2 have failed to be completely bowled over, and that was only because one doesn't really eat steak, and the other got a mixed-up steak with the guy next to him who had ordered well-done.

L1WwsWj_QXZgorc6U7FEKQ.text: OK, the meat was good. But what blew me away was the CORNFLAKE ICE-CREAM MILSHAKE. Oh my God, I though nothing could top last year's chocolate peanut butter malt milkshake in Ohio, but This Was Incredible. TRY IT. Right, back to the meat. We were there on a Sunday so it seemed rude not to go for the rump roast, although we were somewhat confused by the blackboard price as it seemed to suggest you had to pay separately for the meat and the trimmings. Our server quickly reassured us that this wasn't the case, which was a relief as I was not prepared to pay over £25 for a roast dinner! The meat was excellent, as were the trimmings, though the promised bone marrow appeared to be lacking. A decent portion, but no so big that you're unable to move afterwards. The roast, a tasty (and reasonably-priced) glass of prosecco, and a cornflake ice-cream milkshake later, and I was fully set for a day of intense Boris Biking. Thanks, Hawksmoor!

ULGFewyXTs2zDYAfqgriuQ.text: This place is awesome. It doesn't matter if it will be about meaty breakfast, Sunday roast or just steak ... it will be red and very tasteful :-)

oCH9kxA7g1uBXBdc4l1IdQ.text: Awesome steaks! Rich american style side dishes (mac & cheese, sweet potato, triple cooked chips, creamed spinach), don't go here on a tight budget or on a diet!

ngABlNYB-LbdO7F5p8_QPg.text: Tender? no. Tasty? YES!  That's how I sum up my steak experience here.  At first we warned our hosts that taking beef-raised Americano's to a steak place in London was bordering "stupid" but they insisted....and I'm delighted they did.  The combination of great food, unique atmosphere and killer cocktails warmed the ice off my, well, cockles (wherever those are)...and aren't those a type of mollusc?  but I digress.Hawksmoor was great fun and ideal for dates and business dinners alike.  Try a conversation on the merits of beef fed vs corn fed beef for starters.  It'll be a lively one!

92dASBWBIVmMAaZN2cetfA.text: Their steaks are quite good, their sides are simple and very well executed and their wine list is small and up to the point. The service is also very good. What else do you want from a steakhouse?We tried a porterhouse and a rib-eye and they were both really good.But don't expect anything close to a good American Steakhouse. This place is good for London but wouldn't survive in New York.There are a few things though that I did not like:1. The place is quite noisy.2. The steak could have been served in a big plate rather than being squeezed in a small one.3. If you are into corn fed beef you may get disappointed. At the end though it is a matter of taste/choice. The meat served here is excellent quality as well.
